name: al-Birwa
story: A significant Palestinian Arab village with a history stretching back to the Roman period, al-Birwa was known for its olive groves, two schools (one for boys, one for girls), a mosque, a church, and its revered village shrine. It gained cultural prominence as the birthplace of the Palestinian national poet, Mahmoud Darwish. In early June 1948, the village was initially occupied by Zionist forces during Operation Dekel. Displaying remarkable steadfastness, the villagers, with support from the Arab Liberation Army, staged a counter-attack and recaptured their homes for two days to harvest their crops. However, a much larger Israeli military assault followed, forcing a final, permanent expulsion of all inhabitants. The village was then almost entirely razed to the ground, with the Jewish National Fund (JNF) planting forests over the ruins. The settlements of Yas'ur and Ahihud were established on its lands, erasing a center of Palestinian life and culture.

name: al-Damun
story: Situated on the Acre plain, al-Damun was a village with deep historical roots, containing ancient architectural remains and the shrine of the prophet Dhu al-Kifl, mentioned in the Qur'an. Its economy was primarily agricultural, focused on grains, olives, and melons, supplemented by the weaving of mats from nearby rushes. On July 15-16, 1948, during the second stage of Operation Dekel, the village was attacked by the Israeli army's Sheva' (7th) Brigade. Already demoralized by the fall of the major cities of Acre and Nazareth, many villagers fled under the initial heavy shelling. Those who remained were forcibly expelled by the occupying troops. Following the expulsion, Israeli forces systematically destroyed the village, leaving only a few stone houses and the shrine as desolate reminders of a vibrant community.
israeli_settlement: None on village site; lands used by Yas'ur

name: al-Sumayriyya
story: A coastal village north of Acre, known to the Crusaders as 'Someleria,' al-Sumayriyya's economy was based on agriculture, particularly citrus and bananas, and stone quarrying from its ancient caves. The village was captured on May 14, 1948, by the Haganah's Carmeli Brigade during Operation Ben-Ami, an offensive designed to 'cleanse' the coast of Western Galilee. While Israeli sources claim the villagers fled before the attack, Palestinian historians and villagers recount fierce fighting in defense of their homes. Following its capture, a New York Times report confirmed the extensive destruction wrought by 'Jewish demolition squads.' By June 1948, the JNF was already working to completely level the village, an act of erasure that was a key part of the Zionist colonization strategy.

name: al-Bassa
story: Al-Bassa was a large and prosperous mixed Muslim and Christian village in northern Galilee, a hub of social and economic life with two schools, a large church, and a mosque. It was captured on May 14, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. After a brief battle, the village leaders surrendered. According to survivor testimonies documented by historians, a number of men were then rounded up and summarily executed by Haganah soldiers in a house that was subsequently blown up. The majority of the Christian population was initially herded into the village church, while Muslims were expelled to a nearby village. A few days later, all remaining inhabitants were forcibly expelled at gunpoint across the border into Lebanon, becoming refugees. The village was systematically leveled, though its church and mosque were left standing amidst the rubble.

name: al-Tira
story: Known as 'Tira of the almonds' (Tirat al-Lawz), this was one of the largest and most important villages in the Haifa sub-district, with a history dating to the Roman era. It was a major producer of olives and oil, with several modern presses. Al-Tira faced a series of attacks beginning in December 1947, including a deadly Irgun bombing of a coffeehouse. The village finally fell on July 16, 1948, during the fierce 'Ten Days' battles that followed the first truce. The assault was notable for being the first coordinated land-sea attack by Israeli forces; a warship bombarded the village from the Mediterranean before ground units from the Golani, Carmeli, and Alexandroni brigades moved in. The remaining villagers were expelled, and the village was almost entirely demolished, with the new Israeli town of Tirat Carmel built over its ruins.
destroyed_by: Irgun (IZL), Haganah (Golani, Carmeli, Alexandroni Brigades), Israeli Navy
israeli_settlement: Tirat Carmel, Kfar Galim, HaHotrim, Megadim, Beit Tzvi

name: Ayn Ghazal
story: Ayn Ghazal was part of the 'Little Triangle' of resilient villages south of Haifa that held out against Zionist forces for months after the fall of the city. The village, which had a history of resistance dating back to the 1936-39 Arab revolt, was finally captured on July 26, 1948, during Operation Shoter ('Operation Policeman'). This was a massive, coordinated assault involving intense artillery shelling and, significantly, aerial bombardment by B-17 bombers. After its capture, UN investigators documented evidence of atrocities, including the killing of civilians. All remaining inhabitants were expelled, and the village was then systematically destroyed by the IDF over several days, an act of retribution and erasure.

name: Ijzim
story: A large and ancient village in the 'Little Triangle' with Ayn Ghazal, Ijzim had a history dating back to the Roman period and was home to a mosque, a church, and a shrine for a local sage. It was a center of steadfast resistance, holding out for months against Israeli encroachment. It finally fell on July 26, 1948, during the overwhelming assault of Operation Shoter, which involved heavy artillery and air power. After the village's fall, its remaining population was rounded up and expelled, with most forced towards Jinin. In the following weeks, the IDF systematically demolished the village's houses, leaving only the fortress-like home of a notable family and the mosque. The settlement of Kerem Maharal was later established on its lands.

name: al-Tantura
story: An ancient coastal fishing village built on the ruins of the Canaanite city of Dor, al-Tantura had a vibrant economy based on fishing, agriculture, and trade. It was captured on the night of May 22-23, 1948, by the Haganah's Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Namal ('Operation Port'). Following its surrender, a large-scale massacre occurred. Survivor testimonies and research by Israeli scholars have revealed that dozens of unarmed men were systematically executed by the soldiers—lined up and shot on the beach and in the village cemetery. The remaining population was then expelled, with women and children sent to a nearby village and the surviving men taken as prisoners. A mass grave is believed to exist under what is now the parking lot for Dor Beach, a fact that remains a subject of intense denial and controversy in Israel.

name: Ein Karem
story: A prosperous and picturesque village west of Jerusalem, Ein Karem holds deep significance in Christian tradition as the birthplace of John the Baptist. It was a mixed Muslim and Christian community with several churches, monasteries, and a mosque. Its fate was sealed by the fall of surrounding villages and the terror spread by the Deir Yassin massacre. After being shelled on July 10, 1948, it was occupied between July 17-21 during Operation Dani. Most of its 3,000 inhabitants had already fled the bombardment; the few who remained were expelled. Unlike most other villages, its beautiful stone houses were not demolished but were quickly settled by new Jewish immigrants and incorporated into the Jerusalem municipality, an act of cultural appropriation rather than physical erasure.

name: Salama
story: A large and densely populated village east of Jaffa, Salama had strong commercial ties to the city and a vibrant community with two schools and two mosques. Due to its strategic location, it faced constant attacks from Zionist militias for five months, starting in December 1947. A major Haganah attack on January 18, 1948, had the explicit aim 'to cause deaths, blow up houses and to burn everything possible.' The village was finally occupied on April 29, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Hametz, which aimed to encircle and isolate Jaffa. The inhabitants were completely expelled, and its lands were later absorbed into the expanding urban sprawl of Tel Aviv.
israeli_settlement: Kfar Shalem, Neve Eliezer, Nir Aviv (Tel Aviv suburbs)

name: al-'Abbasiyya
story: Formerly known as al-Yahudiyya ('the Jewish town'), this large village east of Jaffa was renamed al-'Abbasiyya in 1932. It had a thriving agricultural economy. The Irgun (IZL) militia first attacked in December 1947, planting bombs in the village. The village was finally occupied by Irgun forces on May 4, 1948, during Operation Hametz, a day after the Haganah had 'cleansed' the surrounding area. All its inhabitants were expelled. In a clear act of policy aimed at preventing any return, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion received cabinet permission in September 1948 to destroy the village. The Israeli town of Yehud now stands on its ruins.
israeli_settlement: Yehud, Magshimim, Ganne Yehuda, Ganne Tiqwa, Savyon

name: Yazur
story: An ancient village on the strategic Jaffa-Ramla highway, Yazur was known since Canaanite times. It was subjected to a series of raids and attacks starting in December 1947. In one notable incident on January 22, 1948, Zionist militia bombed a coffeehouse, killing at least six villagers. The Givati Brigade occupied the village on April 30, 1948, during Operation Hametz. Its population was expelled, and due to its strategic location, it was later used as a military headquarters during the assault on Lydda and Ramla (Operation Dani). The Israeli settlement of Azor was established on its site, and its lands were absorbed by the city of Holon.

name: al-Lajjun
story: A strategically vital village near the ancient site of Megiddo (Armageddon), al-Lajjun stood on the ruins of the Roman city of Legio. It was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 30, 1948, shortly after British forces withdrew from a nearby police fort. The Haganah's operational orders for the assault, as documented by Israeli historians, explicitly stated, 'The inhabitants of the village should be expelled.' Most residents fled under a heavy mortar barrage, and the few who remained were forced out at gunpoint. Immediately following the expulsion, the village was systematically dynamited and destroyed. Kibbutz Megiddo was established on its ruins, erasing a site of immense historical significance.

name: Lifta
story: An ancient and architecturally stunning village at the western entrance to Jerusalem, identified with the biblical town of Nephtoah. Lifta's depopulation began early, marking one of the first instances of ethnic cleansing in the Jerusalem corridor. On December 28, 1947, the Stern Gang (Lehi) and Irgun militias attacked a coffeehouse with machine-gun fire, killing six villagers. This attack initiated a period of intense fear, as Haganah, Irgun, and Lehi forces continued to fire on the village from surrounding high ground. The final expulsion occurred by February 1948 after a campaign of intimidation and strategic destruction of key buildings. While many of its original stone houses remain standing in an eerie, ghost-like state, they are derelict, and the village has been targeted for luxury development, threatening its physical memory.
israeli_settlement: Givat Shaul, Romema, Kiryat Moshe (West Jerusalem suburbs)

name: Deir Yassin
story: A prosperous village on a hill west of Jerusalem, Deir Yassin was known for its limestone quarries and had established a non-aggression pact with neighboring Jewish communities. On April 9, 1948, despite its declared neutrality, the village was attacked by over 120 men from the Irgun (IZL) and Lehi (Stern Gang) militias, with covering fire from the Haganah's Palmach units. What followed was a deliberate massacre. Over 100 villagers—men, women, and children—were systematically killed, many executed in cold blood inside their homes or after being paraded through Jerusalem. The news of the massacre was strategically publicized by the perpetrators to spread terror among the Palestinian population, becoming a pivotal event that accelerated the flight of refugees from other areas. The Givat Shaul Bet neighborhood and the Kfar Shaul Mental Health Center were built on its lands, with some of the original village buildings being incorporated into the hospital.
destroyed_by: Irgun (IZL), Lehi, with Haganah (Palmach) covering fire
israeli_settlement: Givat Shaul Bet, Har Nof, Kfar Shaul Mental Health Center

name: al-Qastal
story: A small but strategically vital village built around a Roman and Crusader fort (Castellum) that commanded the main Jaffa-Jerusalem highway. Al-Qastal became the site of one of the most famous battles of the 1948 war. It was a critical target of Operation Nachshon, the Haganah's first major offensive to break the siege of Jerusalem. It was initially occupied by the Palmach on April 3, 1948. A fierce multi-day battle ensued, during which the charismatic Palestinian commander 'Abd al-Qadir al-Husayni was killed while leading a counter-attack. After its final capture on April 8-9, Palmach units systematically blew up the village's houses, setting a precedent for the destruction of other villages in the corridor. The Israeli settlement of Ma'oz Tziyyon, later merged into Mevasseret Zion, was built on its site.

name: al-Maliha
story: A large suburban village southwest of Jerusalem, known for its fine stone houses and agricultural land. The depopulation of al-Maliha occurred in stages. A first wave of residents fled in fear after the Deir Yassin massacre in April 1948. The village was finally attacked and occupied on the night of July 13-14, 1948, by Irgun (IZL) militia and Gadna youth battalions during operations to consolidate Israeli control around Jerusalem. The remaining inhabitants were forcibly expelled. Unlike many other villages, its substantial stone houses were left intact and were quickly occupied by Jewish immigrants, primarily from Iraq. The village's lands were incorporated into Jerusalem and are now covered by the suburbs of Manahat and Givat Masua.
israeli_settlement: Manahat, Ramat Denya, Givat Masua, Ir Ganim (Jerusalem suburbs)

name: Qalunya
story: A village on the main Jaffa-Jerusalem highway, identified with the Roman settlement of Colonia Amosa and the biblical town of Motza. It was a primary target of Operation Nachshon due to its strategic position. On April 11, 1948, following the battle for al-Qastal, Palmach units from the Harel Brigade entered Qalunya. According to Israeli military records, the remaining inhabitants were ordered out before the soldiers systematically blew up at least 50 of its stone houses, leaving the village ablaze. This act of deliberate destruction was one of the first of its kind in the Jerusalem corridor and served as a clear message to other Palestinian communities. The Israeli settlement of Mevasseret Zion was later established on its lands.

name: Saris
story: A village perched on a high plateau west of Jerusalem, Saris was known for its olive groves and grain fields. It was attacked and demolished by the Haganah's Harel Brigade on April 16, 1948, during Operation Nachshon. The attack was part of a broader strategy to clear the Bab al-Wad area of its Palestinian population. A report in The Scotsman newspaper noted the destruction of the village's mosque, school, and 25 houses, with another 25 damaged. Just before the attack, Haganah chief Israel Galili requested that a Zionist settlement be established at Saris 'as soon as possible' for security reasons, revealing the pre-meditated plan of replacement that followed expulsion and destruction. The Israeli settlement of Shoresh was later built on its ruins.

name: Suba
story: Located on a strategic mountaintop west of Jerusalem, Suba was built within the ruins of the formidable Crusader fortress of Belmont. Its houses were clustered inside the castle's ancient walls. The village was captured on the night of July 12-13, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Dani. According to an Associated Press report at the time, the village was taken 'without combat after a bombardment that drove the Arab defenders' from the strategic heights. The residents who had not already fled the shelling were expelled. The site was later used to establish Kibbutz Tzova, and a forest was planted over much of the village lands, obscuring its history.

name: Bayt Mahsir
story: A large village on a high ridge overlooking the coastal plain, Bayt Mahsir was a Palestinian stronghold that controlled access to the Bab al-Wad (Sha'ar HaGai) pass, a critical point on the Jerusalem road. It was captured by the Palmach's Harel Brigade on May 11, 1948, after three nights of fierce attacks during Operation Makkabi. The battle was intense, with the village changing hands multiple times. After its final capture, the village was systematically leveled with explosives. The destruction was so complete that by August, one Israeli official reported that the site was 'one of the beautiful ruins' created by the war. The settlements of Beit Meir and Mesilat Zion were established on its lands.

name: Kasla
story: A village situated on a mountaintop west of Jerusalem, Kasla is identified with the biblical city of Chesalon. It was depopulated during Operation Dani and subsequently 'cleansed' on July 16-18, 1948, by the Harel Brigade as part of an effort to widen the corridor to Jerusalem. Most villagers had either left earlier due to the fighting and fear spreading from nearby villages, fled under the mortar barrages that preceded the Israeli attack, or were expelled by the occupying troops upon their arrival. The village was then completely destroyed, and the Jewish National Fund later planted a forest over the site, which is now part of the Ksalon National Park.

name: Qula
story: A strategically important village with a history stretching back to the Crusaders, who built a fortress there, Qula was a key objective during Operation Dani. It was first captured by the Alexandroni Brigade on July 10, 1948. However, the Jordanian Arab Legion launched a fierce counter-attack and recaptured it. It was taken permanently by Israeli forces on July 18 after a bloody battle that resulted in heavy casualties for the Alexandroni Brigade. Following its capture, all of its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was systematically destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Giv'at Ko'ah was established on its land, and a forest was planted over its ruins.

name: Isdud
story: An ancient and large village built on the site of the biblical Philistine city of Ashdod, Isdud was a key commercial and agricultural center on the southern coastal plain. During the 1948 war, it became a key frontline position occupied by the Egyptian army. As a result, it was subjected to heavy and repeated aerial and naval bombardment during Operation Yoav. On October 28, 1948, as Israeli forces advanced, the Egyptian army withdrew southwards, and the vast majority of the civilian population, fearing for their lives, fled with them. The approximately 300 villagers who remained, hoping to stay in their homes, were immediately rounded up by Israeli forces and forcibly expelled by truck to the Gaza strip, an act witnessed by UN observers. The modern Israeli city of Ashdod was built nearby.
israeli_settlement: Ashdod, Sde Uziyahu, Shtulim, Bene Darom, Gan HaDarom

name: al-Faluja
story: A large village that became internationally known as the site of the 'Faluja pocket,' where 4,000 Egyptian troops, including a young officer named Gamal Abdel Nasser, were besieged by Israeli forces for several months. The 1949 Armistice Agreement signed between Israel and Egypt explicitly stipulated that the 3,140 Palestinian civilians in al-Faluja and the neighboring village of Iraq al-Manshiyya would be allowed to remain safely in their homes under Israeli rule. However, Israeli forces immediately violated this provision. Over several weeks, they engaged in a campaign of terror and intimidation—including beatings, threats, and nighttime raids—to force all inhabitants to leave. By April 1949, the entire civilian population had been expelled to Hebron and Gaza. The village was then completely destroyed and the city of Kiryat Gat was built on its lands.
israeli_settlement: Kiryat Gat, Plugot Forest, Shahar, Noga, Nir Hen, Nehora

name: Iraq Suwaydan
story: The strategic importance of Iraq Suwaydan was defined entirely by the formidable British police station (a Tegart fort) that dominated the village and the surrounding landscape. This fort became a key stronghold for the Egyptian army. Israeli forces launched eight separate and costly attempts to capture the fort between May and November 1948, all of which were repulsed, turning the fort into a symbol of humiliating failure for the IDF. It finally fell on November 9, 1948, during Operation Yoav, after a massive, coordinated assault involving heavy artillery, commando raids, and a devastating aerial bombardment that included strikes from B-17 bombers. The village itself, whose inhabitants had likely fled during the intense and prolonged fighting, was occupied and subsequently destroyed. The settlements of Yad Natan and Otzem, along with Sde Yo'av, were later established on its lands.

name: al-Masmiyya al-Kabira
story: Al-Masmiyya al-Kabira ('the large Masmiyya') was a major village located at a critical road junction on the southern coastal plain. It had a vibrant community with a mosque, two elementary schools, and a thriving market. Its inhabitants were primarily engaged in agriculture, cultivating grain and citrus. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade on July 9-11, 1948, during Operation An-Far ('An-Far' being an abbreviation for Anti-Farouk), an offensive designed to clear the flanks of the main Israeli thrust southwards. The capture was part of 'clearing operations' intended to secure the rear guard of the front line against Egyptian forces. All of its inhabitants were expelled upon its capture, and the village was later completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Bnei Re'em, Hatzav, and Yinnon were built on its land.

name: Saffuriyya
story: The largest and most prominent village in the Nazareth sub-district, Saffuriyya was built on a strategic hill over the ruins of the ancient Roman-Jewish capital of Galilee, Sepphoris. It was a thriving agricultural center with a rich history, a large mosque, a convent, and an orphanage. The village was occupied on the night of July 15-16, 1948, during Operation Dekel. According to Israeli military archives, the village 'put up strong resistance,' which led to an order for a heavy aerial bombardment using 'barrel bombs'—a primitive but devastating weapon. The bombing caused numerous casualties and widespread panic, prompting the flight of many residents. The remaining villagers were forcibly expelled in the following days. A small number who managed to return were rounded up and expelled again in January 1949, a common practice to ensure permanent depopulation. The Israeli settlement of Tzippori now stands on the site.
israeli_settlement: Tzippori, HaSolelim, Allon HaGalil, Hoshaya, Hanton

name: al-Mujaydil
story: A large mixed Muslim and Christian village strategically located on the Nazareth-Haifa highway, al-Mujaydil was known for its trade and agriculture. It was occupied by the Golani Brigade on July 14-15, 1948, during the early stages of Operation Dekel. The attack on al-Mujaydil served as a strategic diversion for the main Israeli assault on the city of Nazareth. Following its capture, al-Mujaydil was completely emptied of its inhabitants, who were forced to flee towards Nazareth and other nearby villages. In the years that followed, the village was systematically razed to the ground to make way for the establishment and expansion of the Israeli development town of Migdal HaEmek, an act of demographic transformation central to the colonization of Galilee.

name: Ma'lul
story: A predominantly Christian village west of Nazareth, Ma'lul had a history dating back to at least the Roman era. Its residents were known for their close social and economic ties with Nazareth. The village was occupied on July 15, 1948, during Operation Dekel, just one day before the capture of Nazareth itself. Its inhabitants were expelled, with many taking refuge in Nazareth and Yafa, where they and their descendants live today as 'present absentees'—internally displaced citizens denied the right to return to their homes. The village was completely leveled, with the exception of its two churches (one Greek Catholic, one Roman Catholic) and its mosque, which stand today as stark, lonely witnesses in a pine forest planted over the ruins by the Jewish National Fund (JNF).

name: 'Allar
story: A village perched on a rocky hill in the Jerusalem corridor, 'Allar's economy was based on agriculture, primarily grains, vegetables, and olives from which oil was pressed in a local mill. The village was depopulated on October 22, 1948, during Operation ha-Har, an offensive by the Harel Brigade aimed at clearing the region south of the Jerusalem-Jaffa road. The operation involved systematically taking village after village, causing inhabitants to flee from the advancing forces and shelling. After its capture, 'Allar was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mata and parts of the 'American Independence Park,' funded by the Jewish National Fund, were established on its lands.

name: 'Aqqur
story: A small village situated in the Jerusalem mountains, 'Aqqur was depopulated on July 13-14, 1948, during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of a broader clearing operation in the Jerusalem corridor conducted by the Harel Brigade. Like its neighbors, the villagers were either expelled or fled in terror from the advancing Israeli forces. The village shrine, dedicated to a local sage named Shaykh Ahmad al-'Aqqari, was a notable landmark. After the war, the village was completely leveled. Today, the Martyrs' Forest (Ya'ar ha-Kdoshim), a JNF project, covers the site, its trees planted to obscure the ruins and erase the memory of Palestinian life.
israeli_settlement: Sorek Stream North Nature Reserve, Martyrs' Forest

name: 'Artuf
story: A small village located near the Jewish settlement of Hartuv, 'Artuf had a complex history of interaction with its neighbors. The village was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during Operation Dani, as the Harel Brigade expanded its control west of Jerusalem. The villagers were driven out, and their homes were subsequently destroyed. The pre-1948 settlement of Hartuv was expanded after the war, and the new settlement of Naham was also established on the village's lands, contributing to the erasure of the Palestinian presence in the area.

name: Beit 'Itab
story: Built on the remains of an ancient Crusader fortress, Beit 'Itab was a village with a commanding view of the surrounding hills. It was a known stronghold for Palestinian fighters during the war. The village was captured on October 21, 1948, during Operation ha-Har by the Harel Brigade. After a battle, the remaining inhabitants were expelled. Following its capture, the village was systematically destroyed. Today, the site is covered by the Israeli settlements of Nes Harim and Bar Giora, as well as the JNF-planted American Independence Park, which serves to conceal the history of Palestinian habitation and resistance.
israeli_settlement: Nes Harim, Bar Giora, American Independence Park

name: Beit Umm al-Mays
story: A small village situated on a mountain slope, Beit Umm al-Mays was known for its springs and agricultural terraces. It was depopulated around July 1, 1948, during the fighting of Operation Dani. Its proximity to other captured villages and the general offensive by the Harel Brigade led to its evacuation and subsequent occupation. The village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ramat Raziel and the extensive Martyrs' Forest now occupy its former lands, with the forest's trees serving as a living monument to the erasure of Palestinian history.
israeli_settlement: Part of Ramat Raziel, Martyrs' Forest

name: al-Burayj
story: A small village named after a Crusader tower ('al-Burj'), al-Burayj was located in the foothills of the Jerusalem mountains. The village was depopulated on October 1, 1948, during the fighting that followed Operation An-Far. Its capture by the Givati Brigade was part of an effort to link up with forces in the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. A military base and the Israeli settlement of Sedot Mikha were later built on its lands, reflecting the common practice of replacing Palestinian villages with Zionist military and civilian infrastructure.

name: Deir 'Amr
story: Named after a monastery that once stood on the site, Deir 'Amr was a village built on a mountain slope and known for its olive and fruit trees. The village was depopulated on July 14, 1948, during Operation Dani, as the Harel Brigade advanced through the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were forced to flee, and their homes were later demolished. The Eitanim psychiatric hospital was built on the village lands, a particularly stark example of one community's ruins becoming the site for another's institution. The Martyrs' Forest also covers part of the village's former territory.

name: Deir Aban
story: A large village located on the western slopes of the Hebron mountains, Deir Aban had a long history and contained the tomb of a revered local figure. It was captured late in the war, on October 20, 1948, during Operation ha-Har. The Harel Brigade attacked the village, forcing its residents to flee eastwards towards Bethlehem and the Hebron hills. After the expulsion, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli city of Beit Shemesh was later founded nearby and has since expanded onto Deir Aban's lands, along with the settlements of Mahasia, Yish'i, and Tzora.

name: Deir al-Hawa
story: Meaning 'Monastery of the Wind,' Deir al-Hawa was a village perched on a high mountain, making it a natural defensive position. It was attacked and captured on October 20, 1948, by the Harel Brigade as part of Operation ha-Har. According to Israeli military reports, after capturing the village, the soldiers 'blew up' its buildings. The inhabitants were expelled. The site was later planted over with trees to create the American Independence Park, a JNF project designed to obscure the evidence of the destroyed Palestinian community.

name: Deir al-Sheikh
story: A village in the Jerusalem mountains known for its prominent shrine to a Sufi leader, Shaykh Badr. The shrine, with its large dome, was an important local landmark. The village was captured on October 21, 1948, during Operation ha-Har. Its capture by the Harel Brigade led to the expulsion of its residents. While most of the village was destroyed, the historic shrine was left standing, though it has fallen into disrepair. The surrounding area is now part of the Sorek Stream Nature Reserve.

name: Deir Rafat
story: Deir Rafat was a small agricultural village. It should not be confused with the nearby Latin Patriarchate monastery of the same name, which still exists. The Palestinian village was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during Operation Dani, as Israeli forces worked to secure and widen their control over the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were expelled and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Givat Shemesh was later established on the lands of the former village, erasing its presence from the map.

name: Ishwa'
story: A village located in a valley at the foot of the Jerusalem mountains, Ishwa' was known for its grain cultivation. It was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during Operation Dani. The Harel Brigade captured the village as part of its offensive to control the area. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were subsequently demolished. The Israeli settlement of Eshtaol was established on its lands in 1949, and the Jewish National Fund planted the Eshtaol Forest over the site, a common practice of afforestation to prevent the return of refugees and conceal the history of destruction.

name: 'Islin
story: A small village in the Jerusalem foothills, 'Islin was depopulated on July 18, 1948, during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the same sweep by the Harel Brigade that took the neighboring village of Ishwa'. Its residents were forced to flee from the advancing army. Following the expulsion, the village was destroyed. Today, its lands have been partly absorbed by the settlement of Eshtaol and are also covered by the extensive Eshtaol Forest, which was renamed Rabin Park, another layer of erasure.

name: al-Jura
story: A village situated on the western slopes of a mountain, overlooking the coastal plain from a distance, al-Jura was a short distance from Ein Karem. Its population began to flee in April 1948, terrified by the news of the Deir Yassin massacre nearby. The village was finally occupied on July 11, 1948, by Irgun and Lehi militia during the fighting that preceded the second truce. The remaining inhabitants were expelled. The Israeli settlement of Ora was established on its land in 1950. The village site itself now lies within the Ashkelon National Park.

name: al-Lawz, Khirbat
story: Meaning 'the ruin of almonds,' Khirbat al-Lawz was a village built on a steep mountain slope. The village was depopulated on July 13-14, 1948, during Operation Dani. The Harel Brigade captured it as part of its campaign to 'cleanse' the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The site is now covered by the Judean Hills National Park and the Sataf Forest, with the afforestation project serving to obscure the remains of the Palestinian community.
israeli_settlement: Judean Hills National Park, Sataf Forest

name: al-Qabu
story: A small village located in the mountainous terrain southwest of Jerusalem, al-Qabu's economy was tied to agriculture. It was captured on October 22, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation ha-Har. This offensive was designed to clear a broad swath of territory, and al-Qabu was one of many villages depopulated during this sweep. Its residents were expelled, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mevo Betar was established on its lands in 1950, and the area is also part of Begin Park.

name: Ras Abu 'Ammar
story: A village situated on a mountain top, Ras Abu 'Ammar was known for its agricultural produce, which it sold in Jerusalem and Bethlehem. It was captured on October 21, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation ha-Har. The capture of the village was part of a systematic campaign to depopulate the entire region. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Tzur Hadassa was established on its land in 1960, and the site is also covered by the extensive Begin Park.

name: Sar'a
story: Identified with the biblical town of Zorah, Sar'a was a village with a long history, containing a shrine to the prophet Samson. It was captured on July 13-14, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Dani. The assault on Sar'a was part of a wider offensive to secure the area around Bab al-Wad. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed after the capture. The Israeli settlement of Tarum was established on its land in 1950, and the JNF planted the Tzora Forest over the village site.

name: Abu al-Fadl
story: A small village near the large Sarafand military base, Abu al-Fadl was inhabited by people from various clans, many of whom worked at the base. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Barak, an offensive by the Givati Brigade aimed at clearing Palestinian villages south of Tel Aviv. The operation's orders were to compel the villagers to leave, and those who resisted were to be expelled by force. The village was destroyed, and its lands have since been absorbed into the urban areas of Rishon LeZion and the massive military complex of Tzrifin (formerly Sarafand).

name: Abu Shusha
story: Situated near the archaeological mound of Tel Gezer, Abu Shusha was a village whose inhabitants farmed grain, vegetables, and fruit. It was captured on May 14, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Makkabi. A massacre occurred in the village after its capture. According to Israeli military archives and survivor accounts, soldiers killed dozens of villagers, including women. The remaining population was expelled. The village was then completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ameilim, later renamed Karmei Yosef, was established on its land.

name: al-Na'ani
story: A village situated on the coastal plain, al-Na'ani's residents were primarily engaged in agriculture, cultivating grain, sesame, and fruit, particularly citrus. The village was located near the main highway and railway line. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on May 14, 1948, during Operation Barak, an offensive designed to 'cleanse' the area south of Tel Aviv in anticipation of the British withdrawal. The operational orders for the Givati Brigade were explicit: to expel the inhabitants. Following its capture and the expulsion of its residents, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Ramot Meir and Ganne Hadar were later established on its lands.

name: al-Qubab
story: Located on high ground overlooking the coastal plain, al-Qubab was a large and strategically important village. Its inhabitants were known for their stone quarrying and agriculture. The village was attacked and captured on May 15, 1948, during Operation Makkabi. After its capture by the Givati Brigade, there were reports of killings. A UN document from June 1948 notes that the bodies of nine men from al-Qubab were found. The remaining villagers were expelled, and the village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mishmar Ayalon was founded on its land in 1949.

name: al-Barriyya
story: A small village on the coastal plain whose economy was based on grain, vegetable, and fruit farming. Al-Barriyya was depopulated on July 10, 1948, during Operation Dani, in the period known as the 'Ten Days' of fighting between the first and second truces. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade. While some sources suggest the villagers fled, others indicate they were expelled by the attacking force. After the war, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Azarya was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Maghar
story: Al-Maghar was a large village known for its distinctive houses built into a hillside, giving it its name ('The Caves'). The village had a diverse population and a rich history. It was captured on May 15, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak. According to historical accounts, a massacre occurred in the village after its occupation. Soldiers reportedly separated men from the women and children and executed dozens of them. The rest of the population was expelled. The village was later destroyed, and the settlement of Beit Elazari was founded on its lands.

name: Idnibba
story: A village located in the rolling hills of the Shephelah, Idnibba's livelihood depended on agriculture, particularly cereals and olive trees. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. Its capture by the Givati Brigade was part of the offensive aimed at blocking the advance of the Egyptian army. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. No Israeli settlements were built directly on its former site, but its lands were taken over by surrounding settlements.

name: Ajanjul
story: A small village in the Ramle sub-district, Ajanjul's existence was tied to the land and agriculture. It was depopulated during the summer of 1948, likely in July during the widespread Israeli offensives in the area, such as Operation Dani or An-Far. The specific details of its capture are sparse, as it was one of many small communities swept away during the major military operations. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was subsequently erased. Its lands were later absorbed by the state.

name: al-Haditha
story: Al-Haditha was a village with ancient origins, mentioned by the Roman historian Josephus. It was located near the city of Lydda. The village was captured on July 12, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade as part of Operation Dani. Its capture occurred in conjunction with the infamous assault on Lydda and Ramla, which involved a large-scale massacre and the forced expulsion of some 70,000 civilians. The inhabitants of al-Haditha were also expelled. The Israeli settlement of Hadid was established on its ruins in 1949.

name: al-Khayma
story: A village situated on a high, conical hill, al-Khayma was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The operation's objective was to clear the area and create a wedge between Egyptian and Jordanian forces. The Givati Brigade captured the village, and its inhabitants were expelled. The village was later destroyed. In 1955, the Israeli settlement of Revadim was moved onto the village's lands.

name: Khulda
story: A village on the southern coastal plain, Khulda became a frontline position early in the war. The village was first attacked in April 1948, and a number of its houses were blown up by Haganah forces. The final depopulation occurred on July 12, 1948, during Operation Dani. Its capture by the Yiftach Brigade was part of the effort to secure the road to Jerusalem. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The settlement of Mishmar David was established on its lands.

name: al-Kunayyisa
story: Meaning 'The Little Church,' al-Kunayyisa was a village located on rolling terrain. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The Givati Brigade captured the village as it pushed to isolate Egyptian forces in the south. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The site of the former village is now part of an Israeli military area.

name: al-Mansura
story: A small village whose name means 'The Victorious,' al-Mansura was depopulated during the summer of 1948. It was likely captured in July by the Givati Brigade during the major offensives in the area. Like many smaller villages, its specific capture is not heavily documented, but it was part of the general sweep that ethnically cleansed the region. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the nearby settlement of Kfar Menahem.

name: Nabi Rubin
story: Nabi Rubin was not just a village but also a major religious and cultural site, home to a large shrine dedicated to the Prophet Reuben (Nabi Rubin). The site hosted a famous annual festival, or 'mawsim,' that drew tens of thousands of Palestinians from all over the country for weeks of religious ceremonies, trade, and celebration. The village was depopulated on June 1, 1948, during Operation Barak. After the Givati Brigade captured the area, the inhabitants were expelled. The shrine, a major center of Palestinian cultural and religious life, was desecrated and later blown up. The settlement of Gan Sorek was established on its lands.

name: Qazaza
story: A village situated on a low hill, Qazaza's economy revolved around agriculture. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. Captured by the Givati Brigade, its inhabitants were expelled as part of the broader military goal of clearing the southern coastal plain. The village was completely destroyed after the war. The site is now covered by an Israeli military base and forest.

name: Sajad
story: Sajad was a small village whose lands were primarily used for cereal cultivation. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade during its push to control the area and block Egyptian forces. The inhabitants were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Today, the site is overgrown with wild vegetation, and its lands are used by the Israeli settlement of Kfar Menahem.

name: Saydun
story: A small village named after the ancient Lebanese city of Sidon, from where its founders were said to have originated. Saydun was depopulated in the summer of 1948, likely during the major Israeli offensives in July. Its capture was part of the general ethnic cleansing of the Ramle sub-district. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the state and surrounding settlements.

name: Shahma
story: Shahma was a small agricultural village on the southern coastal plain. It was depopulated on May 9, 1948, relatively early in the war, during Operation Barak. The Givati Brigade's orders for the operation involved the expulsion of Palestinian communities to secure the area around future Israeli settlements. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The settlement of Pedaya was established on its lands in 1951.

name: Shilta
story: Located in the Latrun area, Shilta was one of several villages destroyed during Operation Dani in July 1948. After capturing Lydda and Ramla, Israeli forces pushed into the Latrun area, which was designated as a 'no-man's land' in the armistice agreement. However, Israel occupied and destroyed the villages within it to create a sanitized buffer zone. Shilta was occupied and its inhabitants expelled. The village was then completely destroyed, and the settlement of Shilat was established nearby.

name: al-Tina
story: Al-Tina was a village on the southern coastal plain whose residents were farmers. It was depopulated on July 8-9, 1948, at the very beginning of the 'Ten Days' offensive between the two truces. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. Its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Ahim was established on its land in 1949.

name: Tira Dandan
story: Located north of the city of Tulkarm, Tira Dandan (also known as Tira al-Lawz) was a large village with a long history. It was depopulated in May 1948. Its proximity to the coastal area made it an early target for Zionist forces seeking to create a contiguous Jewish-held territory. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli city of Tirat Yehuda was later built on its ruins.

name: Umm Kalkha
story: A small agricultural village, Umm Kalkha was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. Its capture by the Givati Brigade was part of the same offensive that took nearby villages like Sajad and al-Kunayyisa. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was later demolished. Its lands were absorbed by the state and are now farmed by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: al-Imara
story: Al-Imara was a Bedouin village in the northern Negev desert. It was one of many Bedouin localities whose inhabitants were forcibly displaced during and after the 1948 war. It was captured during Operation Yoav in late October 1948. Following the capture of the area, the residents were expelled, part of a wider policy of 'clearing' the Negev of its Bedouin population to make way for Jewish settlement. The Israeli settlements of Urim and Ofakim were established on its lands.

name: Jammama
story: A village in the northern Negev, Jammama was captured on May 22, 1948, by the Negev Brigade during Operation Barak. The operation aimed to drive out Palestinian communities from the areas surrounding Jewish settlements in the south. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ruchama, which had been established nearby, later expanded onto the village's lands.

name: al-Khalasa
story: Al-Khalasa was a Bedouin center on the site of the ancient Nabatean city of Elusa. It was a key location in the Negev desert. The village was captured during Operation Yoav in October 1948. Following the Israeli army's occupation of the area, the inhabitants were forcibly expelled, part of the systematic removal of the Bedouin population from the northern Negev. The village was destroyed, and its extensive archaeological ruins were later designated as an Israeli national park.

name: al-Ashrafiyya
story: Located in the fertile Baysan Valley, al-Ashrafiyya was a village whose residents were primarily farmers. It was captured on May 12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. This operation was designed to seize control of the entire Baysan Valley. Following its capture, the villagers were expelled, and their homes were systematically destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Tirat Zvi, which had been established nearby, later expanded to take over the village's lands.

name: al-Bira
story: A village situated in the Baysan Valley, al-Bira was known for its numerous springs and fertile lands. It was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 16, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The operation aimed to create a continuous strip of Israeli-controlled territory and preempt the entry of Arab armies. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently demolished. The Israeli settlement of Ein ha-Natziv was established on its lands in 1946 and later expanded over the village site after its destruction.

name: al-Fatur
story: A small village situated on the floodplain of the Jordan River, al-Fatur's economy was based on agriculture. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Gideon, an offensive by the Golani Brigade designed to seize control of the entire Baysan Valley before the end of the British Mandate. The operation's orders included the expulsion of the Palestinian population. The villagers of al-Fatur were forced to flee, many seeking refuge across the river in Transjordan. The village was subsequently destroyed, and its lands were taken over by the nearby Israeli settlement of Neve Ur.

name: Farwana
story: Farwana was a village located just south of the city of Baysan, with its economy centered on the cultivation of grains, vegetables, and bananas. The village was captured on May 11-12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. The operation aimed to isolate Baysan and clear the surrounding area of its Palestinian inhabitants. The villagers of Farwana were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely demolished. The Israeli settlement of Revaya was established on its lands in 1952.

name: al-Ghazzawiyya
story: Comprised of a cluster of Bedouin settlements in the fertile Baysan Valley, al-Ghazzawiyya's population were primarily tenant farmers. The area was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 20, 1948. Following the occupation, many of the residents were expelled, while others were subjected to a campaign of harassment and intimidation by local Israeli settlers over the next year to force them to leave. The settlements were eventually destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Maoz Haim and Neve Eitan were established on the lands of the Ghazzawiyya Bedouins.

name: al-Hamidiyya
story: Named after Ottoman Sultan Abdul Hamid II, al-Hamidiyya was a village in the Baysan Valley known for its agriculture. It was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 12, 1948, during Operation Gideon. Like other villages in the valley, its capture was part of a systematic plan to create a 'cleansed' and contiguous territory under Zionist control. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Chemdia, established in 1946, later expanded onto the village's lands.

name: al-Hamra
story: A small village in the southern Baysan Valley, al-Hamra's inhabitants were farmers who cultivated the surrounding fertile lands. The village was depopulated in May 1948 during the Golani Brigade's sweep of the valley in Operation Gideon. Its residents were forced to flee from the advancing Israeli forces, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The site of the former village has been entirely effaced, and its lands are now cultivated by the Israeli settlement of Tirat Zvi.

name: Jabbul
story: Jabbul was an agricultural village located on the plain of the Baysan Valley. It was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 12, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The operation's success depended on the rapid depopulation of the Palestinian villages in the valley to create a secure zone. The inhabitants of Jabbul were expelled, and their village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sdei Trumot was established on its lands in 1951.

name: Kafra
story: A village situated on the southern bank of the Jalud River, Kafra was known for its grain and vegetable crops. It was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 16, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The capture was part of the final phase of the operation to consolidate control over the entire valley. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. Today, the village lands are cultivated by the nearby Israeli settlement of Sde Nachum.

name: Kawkab al-Hawa
story: Perched on a strategic hilltop overlooking the Jordan Valley, Kawkab al-Hawa was built on the site of the magnificent Crusader fortress of Belvoir. The village was involved in fighting early on and was captured on May 21, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. Its strategic location made it a key military objective. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Crusader fortress was later excavated and turned into an Israeli national park, a process that erased the more recent history of the Palestinian village that had existed there for centuries.

name: al-Khunayzir
story: A village located in the northern part of the Baysan Valley, al-Khunayzir's economy was tied to agriculture. It was captured by the Golani Brigade around May 20, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The offensive systematically cleared the valley's villages, and al-Khunayzir was no exception. Its inhabitants were driven out, and the village was demolished. The Israeli settlement of Ein ha-Natziv, founded in 1946, expanded onto the lands of the destroyed village.

name: Masil al-Jizl
story: A small village in the southern end of the Baysan Valley, Masil al-Jizl was depopulated on May 31, 1948. Its capture came shortly after the main offensive of Operation Gideon, as Israeli forces consolidated their control over the area. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sdei Trumot was established nearby and utilizes the former village lands for agriculture.

name: al-Murassas
story: Al-Murassas was a village situated on high ground, giving it a commanding view of the surrounding plains. It was captured on May 16, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. The capture of the village was part of the push to secure the northern part of the valley. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sde Nachum was later established on its lands.

name: Qumya
story: A village of Circassian origin, Qumya was located in the northern Baysan Valley. Though the Circassian community in Palestine generally tried to remain neutral, they were ultimately targeted. Qumya was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 15, 1948, during Operation Gideon. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ein Harod, established much earlier, expanded its agricultural lands to cover the site of the former village.

name: al-Sakhina
story: Named 'the hot one' because of its warm springs, al-Sakhina was a village just southwest of Baysan city. It was captured on May 12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. Its proximity to the city made it an early target in the campaign to isolate and capture Baysan. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Gan HaShlosha (Sachne) and Tel Amal were later built on its lands, with Gan HaShlosha turning the village's natural springs into a popular tourist park.

name: al-Samiriyya
story: Al-Samiriyya was a village in the Baysan Valley that was depopulated during the later stages of Operation Gideon. It was captured around May 27-28, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The operation's goal was total control of the valley, which necessitated the removal of its Palestinian population. The inhabitants of al-Samiriyya were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The lands of the former village were taken over by the nearby Israeli settlements of Geva and Ein Harod.
israeli_settlement: Lands used by Geva, Ein Harod

name: Sirin
story: Located on a strategic basalt hill, Sirin was a village that had a history of resisting British forces during the 1936-39 Arab revolt. It was captured on May 12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. An earlier attack by the Palmach in February had already caused some residents to flee. After its final capture, the remaining villagers were expelled, and the entire village was destroyed. The destruction was so thorough that David Ben-Gurion, visiting the area, noted it approvingly in his diary. The lands of Sirin were later incorporated into the nearby Israeli settlements of Tel Katzir and Gesher.

name: Tall al-Shawk
story: A small village just south of Baysan city, Tall al-Shawk was depopulated on May 12, 1948. It was captured by the Golani Brigade during the initial phase of Operation Gideon. The operation focused on clearing the villages surrounding the city of Baysan to facilitate its capture. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sde Trumot was established nearby and its lands now cover the site of the former village.

name: Umm 'Ajra
story: Umm 'Ajra was a village in the Baysan Valley known for its agriculture. It was one of the many villages systematically depopulated by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. It was captured around May 20, 1948. After its inhabitants were driven out, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sde Eliyahu was established on its lands in 1939 and expanded after the village's destruction.

name: Zab'a
story: Zab'a was a village in the Baysan Valley that had been a site of archaeological interest, containing ancient mosaics. It was captured by the Golani Brigade in May 1948, during Operation Gideon. The operation's swift and systematic nature ensured the entire valley was ethnically cleansed. The inhabitants of Zab'a were expelled, and their village was leveled, erasing both the modern village and damaging its ancient heritage. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Sde Nachum.

name: Abu Shusha
story: Located on the edge of the Jezreel Valley, Abu Shusha was a village whose inhabitants were primarily farmers. It was captured on April 9, 1948, during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The Haganah's operational orders for the area were to 'cleanse' the surrounding villages. Following its capture by the Golani Brigade, the village was systematically destroyed. Reports from the time indicate that a number of villagers, including women and children, were killed. The Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaEmek, established in 1926, expanded its agricultural lands over the site of the destroyed village.

name: Abu Zurayq
story: A small village at the foot of Mount Carmel, Abu Zurayq's economy was based on farming grains and vegetables. It was depopulated on April 12, 1948, during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. As part of a counter-offensive, Haganah forces were ordered to capture and destroy the surrounding Palestinian villages. Abu Zurayq was attacked by units of the Carmeli and Golani brigades, and its inhabitants were forced to flee. The village was then completely demolished.

name: Balad al-Shaykh
story: A large and important village at the foot of Mount Carmel, Balad al-Shaykh was the burial site of Izz ad-Din al-Qassam, the revered Syrian cleric and revolutionary leader. On the night of December 31, 1947, in retaliation for the killing of Jewish workers at the nearby oil refinery, Haganah forces carried out a bloody massacre in the village, attacking homes with gunfire and grenades and killing up to 60 civilians, including women and children. This attack caused a mass exodus. The village was finally occupied on April 25, 1948, and the remaining inhabitants were expelled. It was one of the few villages not completely demolished; its houses were resettled by Jewish immigrants and it was renamed Tel Hanan.

name: Barrat Qisarya
story: A small Bedouin settlement near the ancient Roman ruins of Caesarea, Barrat Qisarya's inhabitants were farmers and laborers. The community was depopulated in February 1948. Haganah forces, under the pretext of security, began systematically demolishing houses in the area, forcing the residents to leave. This was an early example of the policy of clearing the coastal plain of its Arab population. The modern Israeli town of Caesarea was later developed on and around the site.

name: Butaymat
story: Butaymat was a small village in the hills southeast of Haifa. It was depopulated in April 1948, during the series of attacks and counter-attacks around the Jewish settlement of Mishmar HaEmek. The village was one of several in the area that was cleared by Haganah forces to create a secure zone. Its inhabitants were forced to flee from the fighting and the advance of Israeli troops. The village was subsequently destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: Hawsha
story: Hawsha was a village located on a hill in the western Galilee, part of a cluster of villages that included al-Kasayir and Khirbat al-Damun. It was captured on April 16, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade. The battle for Hawsha was fierce, with villagers putting up a strong defense alongside the Arab Liberation Army. After its capture, the village was used as a military base by Israeli forces. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Usha, which was founded nearby, expanded onto its lands.

name: al-Jalama
story: Al-Jalama was a village located at a strategic crossroads east of Haifa. It was captured on April 30, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Bi'ur Hametz ('Passover Cleaning'), the same offensive that secured Haifa. The capture of al-Jalama helped to secure the main road and cut off Haifa from the east. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar HaMaccabi, established nearby, took over its lands.

name: al-Kasayir
story: Al-Kasayir was a small village, part of a cluster with Hawsha and Khirbat al-Damun in the western Galilee hills. The village was captured on April 16, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade after a fierce battle. The defense of these villages by the Arab Liberation Army and local militia was strong, but they were ultimately overwhelmed by the Haganah forces. Following its capture, al-Kasayir was completely destroyed to prevent its inhabitants from returning. The Israeli settlement of Usha, established nearby in 1937, expanded its farmlands over the ruins of the destroyed village.

name: Kafr Lam
story: An ancient coastal village built on the site of a Crusader settlement, Kafr Lam was known for its agriculture, particularly grain and vegetables. The village was captured on July 16, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Shoter, the same operation that captured the 'Little Triangle' villages. Its capture was part of the final push to secure the coastline south of Haifa. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were subsequently demolished, with the exception of the village mosque and the tomb of a local religious figure. The Israeli settlements of Ein Ayala and HaBonim were later established on its lands.

name: al-Mansi
story: Al-Mansi was a prominent village in the Jezreel Valley, located near a strategic crossroads. It was one of the first villages in the area to be attacked during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. On April 12, 1948, Haganah forces from the Golani Brigade attacked and occupied the village. According to historical accounts, a number of villagers were killed during the assault. The rest of the population was forced to flee. The village was then completely destroyed to ensure it could not be reoccupied or used as a base by Arab forces. Its lands were later taken over by the nearby Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaEmek.

name: al-Mazar
story: A village located on the southern slopes of Mount Carmel, al-Mazar was part of the 'Little Triangle' of steadfast villages that included 'Ayn Ghazal and Ijzim. It resisted capture for months. Al-Mazar was finally depopulated along with its neighbors during Operation Shoter on July 25-26, 1948. The massive Israeli offensive involved heavy artillery and aerial bombardment. The villagers who had not fled the bombardment were expelled, and the village was systematically destroyed by the IDF to prevent any possibility of return.

name: Qannir
story: Qannir was a village located in the rolling hills of the Menashe region, its economy based on cereal farming. It was captured on April 27, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during the 'clearing' of the coastal plain that took place between the major offensives of Nachshon and Barak. The operation aimed to secure the area and remove its Palestinian population. The villagers of Qannir were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Regavim was established on its lands.

name: Qira
story: A village situated on a low hill on the western edge of the Jezreel Valley, Qira's inhabitants were farmers. The village was captured on April 29, 1948, by units of the Alexandroni and Golani brigades during the final stages of the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The capture was part of a wider operation to secure the entire area for Zionist control. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Yokneam, which had been founded in the 1930s, expanded onto the lands of the destroyed village.

name: al-Rihaniyya
story: A small village in the Menashe hills, al-Rihaniyya was known for its grain fields and vegetable patches. It was captured on April 30, 1948, by the Irgun (IZL) militia, operating in coordination with the Haganah during the coastal clearing operations. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely destroyed. The lands of the former village were later absorbed by the state and nearby Israeli settlements.
israeli_settlement: Lands now part of Ramot Menashe Park

name: Sabbarin
story: Sabbarin was a large and prosperous village in the southern Carmel foothills, known for its extensive agricultural lands and numerous springs. The village was captured on May 12, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade. According to Haganah radio, the villagers put up a 'strong defense' before being overwhelmed. After its capture, the villagers were expelled, and the village was systematically destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Amikam and Ramot Menashe were later established on its extensive lands.

name: al-Sarafand
story: A coastal village south of Haifa, al-Sarafand's economy was based on agriculture and fishing. It was captured on July 16, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Shoter. Its capture was part of the final push to clear the coastal strip between Haifa and Zichron Ya'akov. The inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Tzerufa was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Sindiyana
story: Meaning 'The Oak Tree,' al-Sindiyana was a village in the Carmel foothills. It was one of the villages in the 'Little Triangle' that resisted capture for months. The village was finally captured by the Alexandroni Brigade on May 12, 1948. Following its occupation, the villagers were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed, its houses dynamited by Israeli forces. The settlement of Bat Shlomo, established earlier, expanded its lands over the site of the destroyed village.

name: Umm al-Shawf
story: A village located in the southern Carmel range, Umm al-Shawf was depopulated on May 12, 1948. It was captured by the Alexandroni Brigade as part of its operation to clear the coastal plain and its hinterland. The villagers were forced to flee their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Givat Nili was established on its lands in 1953.

name: Umm al-Zinat
story: A large village on the eastern slopes of Mount Carmel, Umm al-Zinat was known for its grain and olive cultivation. It was captured on May 15, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The capture was part of a broader effort to secure the roads and hinterland around Haifa. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was completely demolished. The Israeli settlement of Elyakim was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Wa'arat al-Sarris
story: A small village located near the Kishon River, Wa'arat al-Sarris was depopulated in late April 1948. The village was captured during the operations that followed the fall of Haifa, as Haganah forces worked to clear the surrounding smaller Arab communities. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later absorbed by the growing industrial zones and settlements around Haifa.

name: Wadi Ara
story: Wadi Ara was not a single village but a collection of hamlets and Bedouin encampments along the strategic Wadi Ara road. The area was cleared by Haganah forces in late April and early May 1948. The operations were aimed at securing this vital transportation artery. The residents were systematically expelled from their homes and lands, and many of the smaller settlements were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Barkai was established in the area in 1949.

name: Yajur
story: An ancient village at the southeastern entrance to Haifa, Yajur's history stretched back to the Canaanite period. It was captured on April 25, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Bi'ur Hametz. Its capture was critical for securing the approaches to Haifa. Following its occupation, the remaining villagers were expelled. Yajur was one of the few villages not entirely demolished; some of its houses were taken over by the adjacent Kibbutz Yagur.

name: 'Ajjur
story: 'Ajjur was a large, centrally located village in the Hebron foothills, serving as a commercial hub for surrounding communities. It was captured on October 23, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Yoav. The operation was designed to drive a wedge into Egyptian forces, and 'Ajjur's capture was a key objective. The villagers were shelled and then expelled from their homes, fleeing east into the Hebron hills. The village was later completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Agur, Tzafririm, and Givat Yeshayahu were established on its extensive lands.

name: Barqusya
story: A small village in the western Hebron district, Barqusya was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948. It was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. The offensive aimed to clear the area in the face of the advancing Egyptian army. The inhabitants of Barqusya were expelled, and their village was destroyed. The site of the village is now deserted, and its lands are used for agriculture by nearby Israeli settlements.
israeli_settlement: Lands now part of 'Yoav' Regional Council

name: Bayt Jibrin
story: An ancient and historically significant town, Bayt Jibrin was the Roman city of Eleutheropolis. In 1948, it was a large Palestinian town and a major commercial and social center. It was captured on October 27, 1948, during Operation Yoav, after being shelled by Israeli forces. Most of its inhabitants fled during the attack, and those who remained were systematically expelled in the following days and weeks. The town was largely destroyed, though some historic buildings remain. Kibbutz Beit Guvrin was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Bayt Nattif
story: A village located in the Hebron hills, Bayt Nattif was a site of significant resistance against Zionist forces. It was captured on October 21, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation ha-Har, after a fierce battle. Following its capture, the villagers were expelled. Israeli historian Benny Morris notes that Bayt Nattif was one of several villages where atrocities were reported, with a number of prisoners being killed. The village was then completely destroyed. The settlements of Netiv HaLamed-Heh and Aviezer were established on its lands.

name: al-Dawayima
story: Al-Dawayima was a large village west of Hebron. On October 29, 1948, it was the site of one of the largest and most brutal massacres of the war. The 89th Commando Battalion, whose soldiers included future Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and future General Moshe Dayan, entered the village and systematically murdered hundreds of unarmed civilians. The massacre began in the village mosque where dozens were killed at prayer, and continued in houses and caves where villagers sought refuge. Men, women, and children were killed indiscriminately. The remaining inhabitants fled in terror. The massacre was covered up by Israeli authorities for decades. The settlement of Amatzya was established on its lands.

name: Deir al-Dubban
story: Meaning 'Monastery of the Flies,' this village was known for its numerous caves, some of which were ancient burial sites. It was captured on October 23-24, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Yoav. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Luzit was established on its lands in 1955, with its name referencing the almond groves for which the Palestinian village was known.

name: Deir Nakhkhas
story: A village located in the western Hebron district, Deir Nakhkhas was depopulated during Operation Yoav. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on October 29, 1948, the same day as the nearby Dawayima massacre. The terror from that event likely spurred the flight of Deir Nakhkhas's residents. Those who did not flee were expelled. The village was subsequently destroyed. Its lands are now used for grazing by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: Kidna
story: Kidna was a village in the Hebron foothills. It was depopulated on October 29, 1948, during Operation Yoav. Its capture by the Givati Brigade coincided with the occupation of Bayt Jibrin and the massacre at al-Dawayima, events which caused widespread panic and flight throughout the region. The villagers of Kidna were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The area was later declared a closed military zone.

name: Mughallis
story: A small village in the Hebron district, Mughallis was captured on July 9-10, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. This early offensive in the south aimed to clear villages in the path of the Egyptian army. The inhabitants of Mughallis were expelled, and their village was completely demolished after the war. The Israeli settlement of Gefen was established on its lands in 1955.

name: al-Qubayba
story: Not to be confused with the village of the same name near Jerusalem, this al-Qubayba was located in the western Hebron district. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on October 28, 1948, during Operation Yoav. This was part of the final push to clear the southern front. After the villagers were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Lakhish was established on its lands in 1955.

name: Ra'na
story: Ra'na was a village situated on a hilly, rocky area in the western Hebron district. Its residents, organized by clan, relied on grain farming and raising livestock. The village was captured on October 22-23, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Yoav. The offensive aimed to clear the southern front, and Ra'na was one of many villages to be ethnically cleansed. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed after the war. The Israeli settlement of Gal'on, which was established nearby in 1946, expanded its agricultural lands over the site of the destroyed village.

name: Zakariyya
story: A large village in the Hebron foothills, Zakariyya was known for its mosque built in honor of the prophet Zechariah, who was believed to be buried there. The village was captured during Operation Yoav, but its inhabitants were not immediately expelled. They remained in the village until 1950, when they were systematically driven out by Israeli authorities. In a multi-stage expulsion, residents were forcibly transported to the cities of Ramla and Lydda, and from there to refugee camps in the West Bank. The village was then resettled by Jewish immigrants and renamed Zekharia. It stands as a stark example of post-armistice ethnic cleansing.

name: Zayta
story: Zayta was a village in the western Hebron district whose inhabitants depended on agriculture. It was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during the second phase of Operation An-Far, or as part of the related 'Death to the Invader' operation. The offensive was conducted by the Givati Brigade to clear the southern front. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely destroyed after the war. Its lands are now part of an area defined by Israel as the 'Plugot forest'.

name: Bayt Dajan
story: An ancient village whose name dates back to a Canaanite deity, Bayt Dajan was a large agricultural center known for its extensive citrus groves. It was captured on April 25, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Hametz. The operation was designed to encircle and ultimately depopulate Jaffa by capturing the surrounding villages. The attack on Bayt Dajan caused many of its residents to flee in terror. The Israeli settlement of Beit Dagan was established on its site in 1948, immediately after the expulsion, and its houses were occupied by new Jewish immigrants.

name: Biyar 'Adas
story: A small village north of Jaffa, Biyar 'Adas was surrounded by orange groves. The village was depopulated very early in the conflict. On March 12, 1948, the Haganah implemented a policy of clearing the coastal plain. Inhabitants were forced out, and on April 3, the Haganah noted that the village's houses 'were occupied'. The Israeli settlement of Adanim was later established nearby, and the village lands were absorbed by the settlement of Hod HaSharon.

name: Fajja
story: Fajja was a village on the coastal plain whose inhabitants were known for their production of high-quality mats from the rushes of the al-Awja river. The village was attacked by the Irgun (IZL) militia on May 15, 1948. The villagers put up a defense but were ultimately overwhelmed. Following its capture, the residents were expelled, and the village was later completely destroyed. The powerful Israeli city of Petah Tikva, one of the earliest Zionist colonies, expanded to engulf the lands of the destroyed village.

name: al-Haram
story: Also known as Sayyidna 'Ali, al-Haram was a coastal village north of Tel Aviv, revered for housing the magnificent shrine of a Muslim saint, 'Ali ibn 'Alim. The village was depopulated in early February 1948 as part of the Haganah's systematic clearing of the coastal plain. Its inhabitants were forced to flee under threat of attack. The beautiful shrine was left standing but has been repeatedly vandalized. The Israeli city of Herzliya, established earlier, expanded its Pitu'ah district onto the village lands, and the ruins of the village now lie next to a beach and tourist area.

name: Ijlil al-Qibliyya
