story: The 'southern' of two adjacent villages named Ijlil, this community was located just north of al-Haram. It was depopulated on April 3, 1948, as part of the same coastal clearing operation conducted by the Alexandroni Brigade. The operation aimed to create a contiguous Jewish-controlled territory along the coast, which required the removal of the Palestinian population. After the villagers were expelled, their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Glil Yam was established on its lands in 1943 and later expanded.

name: Ijlil al-Shamaliyya
story: The 'northern' village of Ijlil, this community was depopulated along with its southern neighbor on April 3, 1948. The Alexandroni Brigade's offensive along the coast was systematic and swift, forcing the inhabitants to abandon their homes and lands under military pressure. The destruction of the Ijlil villages was part of a clear strategic plan to remove the Palestinian presence from the valuable coastal strip north of Tel Aviv. The lands of the village were later absorbed by the Israeli city of Herzliya.

name: al-Jammasin al-Gharbi
story: This was one of two villages inhabited by the Jammasin clan, who were traditionally known for raising water buffaloes. It was located on the north side of the al-'Awja (Yarkon) River. The village was depopulated in March 1948. Haganah forces surrounded the village and, through a campaign of intimidation and the firing of 'a few shots,' coerced the inhabitants into fleeing. The village was then incorporated into the rapidly expanding city of Tel Aviv, and its residents became refugees.

name: al-Jammasin al-Sharqi
story: The 'eastern' village of the Jammasin clan, this community shared the same fate as its western counterpart. It was depopulated in March 1948 as part of the Haganah's effort to clear the immediate hinterland of Tel Aviv. The pressure and intimidation from Zionist forces forced the villagers to abandon their homes and traditional way of life. The village was subsequently demolished and completely absorbed into the urban fabric of Tel Aviv, its history erased by urban development.

name: Jarisha
story: An ancient village located on the banks of the al-'Awja (Yarkon) River, Jarisha was known for its water mills. It was situated very close to Tel Aviv. The village was depopulated in May 1948. Given its location, it was effectively surrounded and cut off. Its inhabitants were forced to leave, and the village was subsequently incorporated into the Israeli city of Ramat Gan, which now covers its former lands. The site is now part of a municipal park.

name: Kafr 'Ana
story: Kafr 'Ana was a large village located near the city of Lydda. It was captured on April 25, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Hametz. The offensive aimed to cut off Jaffa by seizing the surrounding inland villages. Following its capture, the villagers were expelled. The village was later destroyed, and its lands were used to build parts of the Israeli settlements of Or Yehuda and Neve Monosson. Ben Gurion Airport was also expanded onto its lands.

name: al-Khayriyya
story: Originally named Ibn Ibraq after a biblical town, al-Khayriyya was a village east of Jaffa. It was captured on April 29, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Hametz. The operational orders explicitly called for the 'cleansing of the area.' The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. For decades, the site of the former village was used as a massive garbage dump for the Tel Aviv metropolitan area, known as Hiria. It has since been turned into a park named 'Ariel Sharon Park,' a final act of erasure.
israeli_settlement: Ariel Sharon Park (formerly Hiria garbage dump)

name: al-Mas'udiyya
story: Also known as Summayl, al-Mas'udiyya was a village on the outskirts of Tel Aviv, inhabited by the Abu Kishk Bedouin tribe. The village was effectively dismantled on December 25, 1947, in one of the earliest acts of ethnic cleansing in the Jaffa area. Haganah forces surrounded the village and forced its inhabitants to leave for other areas. The village was then demolished to make way for the northward expansion of Tel Aviv. This early expulsion set a precedent for the clearing of the entire coastal plain.

name: al-Mirr
story: A small village located near the larger village of Bayt Dajan, al-Mirr was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured during the wide sweep of Operation Hametz, which aimed to depopulate the entire inland area east of Jaffa. Its inhabitants were expelled along with those of the surrounding villages, and its houses were later destroyed. The lands of al-Mirr were absorbed by the state and are now part of the agricultural lands of nearby Israeli settlements.

name: al-Muwaylih
story: Al-Muwaylih was a small village located northeast of Jaffa, known for its citrus groves. It was depopulated in late January 1948. Haganah forces carried out an attack on the village, blowing up houses and forcing the inhabitants to flee. This was part of the early campaign of intimidation and terror designed to clear Palestinians from the vicinity of Tel Aviv. The village was destroyed, and its lands were later incorporated into the expanding suburbs of Tel Aviv.

name: Rantiya
story: An ancient village with a history going back to the Roman period, Rantiya was located northeast of Lydda. It was captured on July 10, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Dani. The capture of Rantiya was part of the initial phase of the operation that aimed to surround and capture the major cities of Lydda and Ramla. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Rinatya and Mazor were established on its lands.

name: al-Safiriyya
story: Al-Safiriyya was a large and ancient village, known since Byzantine times. It was located on the plain near Lydda. It was captured by Haganah forces on May 20, 1948. An earlier attack by the Irgun in April had already spread fear. After its capture, the villagers were expelled. The village was later completely destroyed, and its lands were used to establish the Israeli settlements of Tzafria and Ahi'ezer, as well as parts of Ben Gurion Airport.

name: Saqiya
story: Saqiya was a village located between al-Khayriyya and Kafr 'Ana. It was captured on April 25, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Hametz. The offensive was designed to create a solid block of Zionist-controlled territory around Jaffa, and the expulsion of the villagers of Saqiya was a necessary component of this plan. The village was destroyed, and the Israeli settlement of Or Yehuda was established on its lands.

name: al-Shaykh Muwannis
story: A large, prosperous, and educated village north of Tel Aviv, al-Shaykh Muwannis was known for its vast citrus groves. Despite having a non-aggression pact with the Haganah, the village was subjected to a campaign of kidnapping and intimidation by Zionist militias. In late March 1948, the Haganah surrounded the village and demanded its residents surrender their weapons. The terror campaign succeeded, and the entire population was forced to flee. The village's houses were not destroyed but were immediately occupied by Jewish immigrants and soldiers. The campus of Tel Aviv University was later built directly on the village lands, with one of the only remaining houses, the 'Green House,' becoming a university club.

name: al-Sawalima
story: Al-Sawalima was a village inhabited by Bedouins, located on the coast north of the al-'Awja river. It was depopulated on March 30, 1948, during the systematic Haganah campaign to clear the coastal plain. The villagers were forced out of their homes under military pressure. The village was subsequently destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the Israeli city of Herzliya.

name: Ayn al-Mansi
story: Ayn al-Mansi was a small village located in the northernmost part of the Jenin sub-district, near the border with the Haifa district. It was depopulated in mid-April 1948 during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The village was caught in the Haganah's counter-offensive, which aimed to clear a wide radius around the embattled kibbutz. Its inhabitants were forced to flee, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into those of the Israeli settlement of Midrakh Oz.

name: Khirbat al-Jawfa
story: A small village in the northeastern Jenin sub-district, on the edge of the Baysan Valley. Khirbat al-Jawfa was depopulated on May 12, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The Golani Brigade's sweep through the Baysan Valley also extended to the edges of the Jenin district, clearing smaller villages like al-Jawfa. Its inhabitants were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The lands were later taken over by the nearby Israeli settlement of Meitav.

name: al-Mazar
story: Located on a mountaintop in the Gilboa range, al-Mazar was a village known for its shrine, which was believed to be the tomb of a companion of the Prophet Muhammad. It was captured on May 31, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The village had resisted earlier attacks. After its capture, the villagers were expelled. The village was later destroyed, with the exception of the shrine. The Israeli settlement of Gan Ner was established on its lands in 1987.

name: Lajjun
story: A historically significant village built on the site of the ancient Roman city of Legio and near the biblical Megiddo, Lajjun was strategically vital. It was captured on May 30, 1948, by the Golani Brigade shortly after British forces withdrew from a nearby police fort. The Haganah's operational orders for the assault explicitly stated, 'The inhabitants of the village should be expelled.' Most residents fled under a heavy mortar barrage, and the few who remained were forced out at gunpoint. Immediately following the expulsion, the village was systematically dynamited and destroyed, an act so definitive that it was noted with satisfaction by David Ben-Gurion. Kibbutz Megiddo was established on its ruins, erasing a site of immense historical importance.

name: Nurit
story: A village located on the slopes of Mount Gilboa, Nurit was known for its agriculture. It was captured on May 30, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The capture was part of a broader operation to secure the area and prevent the intervention of Arab armies. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was used for a time as a military outpost by Israeli forces before being completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Nurit was established on its lands in 1950, directly appropriating the village's name.

name: Zir'in
story: Zir'in was a large and historically prominent village, located on the site of the biblical city of Jezreel. It had a school for boys, a mosque, and a number of historical artifacts. The village was captured on May 28, 1948, by the Golani Brigade after a battle with the Arab Liberation Army. According to Israeli military sources, the capture was followed by the systematic destruction of the village to create a 'clear field of fire.' The villagers were expelled, and Kibbutz Yizra'el was established on its lands in August 1948, with its name being a Hebraicized version of the village's ancient name.

name: 'Ayn Karim
story: A prosperous and picturesque village west of Jerusalem, 'Ayn Karim holds deep significance in Christian tradition as the birthplace of John the Baptist. It was a mixed Muslim and Christian community with several churches, monasteries, and a mosque. Its fate was sealed by the fall of surrounding villages and the terror spread by the Deir Yassin massacre. After being shelled on July 10, 1948, it was occupied between July 17-21 during Operation Dani. Most of its 3,000 inhabitants had already fled the bombardment; the few who remained were expelled. Unlike most other villages, its beautiful stone houses were not demolished but were quickly settled by new Jewish immigrants and incorporated into the Jerusalem municipality, an act of cultural appropriation rather than physical erasure.

name: Bayt Mahsir
story: A large village on a high ridge overlooking the coastal plain, Bayt Mahsir was a Palestinian stronghold that controlled access to the Bab al-Wad (Sha'ar HaGai) pass, a critical point on the Jerusalem road. It was captured by the Palmach's Harel Brigade on May 11, 1948, after three nights of fierce attacks during Operation Makkabi. The battle was intense, with the village changing hands multiple times. After its final capture, the village was systematically leveled with explosives. The destruction was so complete that by August, one Israeli official reported that the site was 'one of the beautiful ruins' created by the war. The settlements of Beit Meir and Mesilat Zion were established on its lands.

name: Bayt Naqquba
story: A small village west of Jerusalem, Bayt Naqquba was depopulated on April 11, 1948, during Operation Nachshon. Its inhabitants were expelled from their homes by the Haganah. However, in an extremely rare case, the villagers were allowed to return to the area after the war, not to their original homes, but to a new village they built nearby called 'Ein Naqquba' in 1962. Their original village site was destroyed and the Israeli settlement of Beit Nekofa was established on its land in 1949. The story of Bayt Naqquba represents both the trauma of expulsion and the unique steadfastness of a community that managed to re-establish itself in the vicinity of its stolen home.

name: Bayt Thul
story: A village located on a mountaintop, Bayt Thul was depopulated in April 1948 during Operation Nachshon. The village was one of many in the Jerusalem corridor cleared by the Haganah to secure the road to the city. Its inhabitants were forced to flee, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Neve Ilan was established on its lands in 1946 and re-established in 1971 after being abandoned.

name: Bayt Umm al-Mays
story: A small village situated on a mountain slope, Bayt Umm al-Mays was known for its springs and agricultural terraces. It was depopulated around July 1, 1948, during the fighting of Operation Dani. Its proximity to other captured villages and the general offensive by the Harel Brigade led to its evacuation and subsequent occupation. The village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ramat Raziel and the extensive Martyrs' Forest now occupy its former lands, with the forest's trees serving as a living monument to the erasure of Palestinian history.
israeli_settlement: Part of Ramat Raziel, Martyrs' Forest

name: Dayr 'Amr
story: Named after a monastery that once stood on the site, Dayr 'Amr was a village built on a mountain slope and known for its olive and fruit trees. The village was depopulated on July 14, 1948, during Operation Dani, as the Harel Brigade advanced through the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were forced to flee, and their homes were later demolished. The Eitanim psychiatric hospital was built on the village lands, a particularly stark example of one community's ruins becoming the site for another's institution. The Martyrs' Forest also covers part of the village's former territory.

name: Dayr Aban
story: A large village located on the western slopes of the Hebron mountains, Dayr Aban had a long history and contained the tomb of a revered local figure. It was captured late in the war, on October 20, 1948, during Operation ha-Har. The Harel Brigade attacked the village, forcing its residents to flee eastwards towards Bethlehem and the Hebron hills. After the expulsion, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli city of Beit Shemesh was later founded nearby and has since expanded onto Dayr Aban's lands, along with the settlements of Mahasia, Yish'i, and Tzora.

name: Dayr al-Hawa
story: Meaning 'Monastery of the Wind,' Dayr al-Hawa was a village perched on a high mountain, making it a natural defensive position. It was attacked and captured on October 20, 1948, by the Harel Brigade as part of Operation ha-Har. According to Israeli military reports, after capturing the village, the soldiers 'blew up' its buildings. The inhabitants were expelled. The site was later planted over with trees to create the American Independence Park, a JNF project designed to obscure the evidence of the destroyed Palestinian community.

name: Dayr Rafat
story: Dayr Rafat was a small agricultural village. It should not be confused with the nearby Latin Patriarchate monastery of the same name, which still exists. The Palestinian village was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during Operation Dani, as Israeli forces worked to secure and widen their control over the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were expelled and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Givat Shemesh was later established on the lands of the former village, erasing its presence from the map.

name: Dayr al-Shaykh
story: A village in the Jerusalem mountains known for its prominent shrine to a Sufi leader, Shaykh Badr. The shrine, with its large dome, was an important local landmark. The village was captured on October 21, 1948, during Operation ha-Har. Its capture by the Harel Brigade led to the expulsion of its residents. While most of the village was destroyed, the historic shrine was left standing, though it has fallen into disrepair. The surrounding area is now part of the Sorek Stream Nature Reserve.

name: Ishwa'
story: A village located in a valley at the foot of the Jerusalem mountains, Ishwa' was known for its grain cultivation. It was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during Operation Dani. The Harel Brigade captured the village as part of its offensive to control the area. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were subsequently demolished. The Israeli settlement of Eshtaol was established on its lands in 1949, and the Jewish National Fund planted the Eshtaol Forest over the site, a common practice of afforestation to prevent the return of refugees and conceal the history of destruction.

name: 'Islin
story: A small village in the Jerusalem foothills, 'Islin was depopulated on July 18, 1948, during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the same sweep by the Harel Brigade that took the neighboring village of Ishwa'. Its residents were forced to flee from the advancing army. Following the expulsion, the village was destroyed. Today, its lands have been partly absorbed by the settlement of Eshtaol and are also covered by the extensive Eshtaol Forest, which was renamed Rabin Park, another layer of erasure.

name: Jirash
story: A small village in the Jerusalem district, Jirash was depopulated in the latter half of 1948. It was captured by the Harel Brigade during Operation Ha-Har in October. The operation was a major offensive to clear the southern Jerusalem corridor, and Jirash was one of many villages to be ethnically cleansed in the process. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Zanoah was established on its lands in 1950.

name: al-Jura
story: A village situated on the western slopes of a mountain, overlooking the coastal plain from a distance, al-Jura was a short distance from Ein Karem. Its population began to flee in April 1948, terrified by the news of the Deir Yassin massacre nearby. The village was finally occupied on July 11, 1948, by Irgun and Lehi militia during the fighting that preceded the second truce. The remaining inhabitants were expelled. The Israeli settlement of Ora was established on its land in 1950. The village site itself now lies within the Ashkelon National Park.

name: Kasla
story: A village situated on a mountaintop west of Jerusalem, Kasla is identified with the biblical city of Chesalon. It was depopulated during Operation Dani and subsequently 'cleansed' on July 16-18, 1948, by the Harel Brigade as part of an effort to widen the corridor to Jerusalem. Most villagers had either left earlier due to the fighting and fear spreading from nearby villages, fled under the mortar barrages that preceded the Israeli attack, or were expelled by the occupying troops upon their arrival. The village was then completely destroyed, and the Jewish National Fund later planted a forest over the site, which is now part of the Ksalon National Park.

name: Khirbat al-Lawz
story: Meaning 'the ruin of almonds,' Khirbat al-Lawz was a village built on a steep mountain slope. The village was depopulated on July 13-14, 1948, during Operation Dani. The Harel Brigade captured it as part of its campaign to 'cleanse' the Jerusalem corridor. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The site is now covered by the Judean Hills National Park and the Sataf Forest, with the afforestation project serving to obscure the remains of the Palestinian community.
israeli_settlement: Judean Hills National Park, Sataf Forest

name: Khirbat al-Tannur
story: A small village or khirba (ruin settlement) in the Jerusalem district, Khirbat al-Tannur was depopulated during Operation Ha-Har in October 1948. The offensive cleared a large number of Palestinian communities in the area. Its few inhabitants were expelled by the advancing Harel Brigade, and the settlement was destroyed. Today, there are no Israeli settlements directly on the site, but its lands have been absorbed by the state.

name: Khirbat al-'Umur
story: Khirbat al-'Umur was a small village situated on a high mountain slope. It was depopulated in two stages. Some villagers fled in April 1948 after the Deir Yassin massacre, while the rest were expelled when the village was occupied by the Harel Brigade on October 21, 1948, during Operation ha-Har. Following the expulsion, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Givat Ye'arim was established on its lands in 1950.

name: Lifta
story: An ancient and architecturally stunning village at the western entrance to Jerusalem, identified with the biblical town of Nephtoah. Lifta's depopulation began early, marking one of the first instances of ethnic cleansing in the Jerusalem corridor. On December 28, 1947, the Stern Gang (Lehi) and Irgun militias attacked a coffeehouse with machine-gun fire, killing six villagers. This attack initiated a period of intense fear, as Haganah, Irgun, and Lehi forces continued to fire on the village from surrounding high ground. The final expulsion occurred by February 1948 after a campaign of intimidation and strategic destruction of key buildings. While many of its original stone houses remain standing in an eerie, ghost-like state, they are derelict, and the village has been targeted for luxury development, threatening its physical memory.
israeli_settlement: Givat Shaul, Romema, Kiryat Moshe (West Jerusalem suburbs)

name: al-Maliha
story: A large suburban village southwest of Jerusalem, known for its fine stone houses and agricultural land. The depopulation of al-Maliha occurred in stages. A first wave of residents fled in fear after the Deir Yassin massacre in April 1948. The village was finally attacked and occupied on the night of July 13-14, 1948, by Irgun (IZL) militia and Gadna youth battalions during operations to consolidate Israeli control around Jerusalem. The remaining inhabitants were forcibly expelled. Unlike many other villages, its substantial stone houses were left intact and were quickly occupied by Jewish immigrants, primarily from Iraq. The village's lands were incorporated into Jerusalem and are now covered by the suburbs of Manahat and Givat Masua.
israeli_settlement: Manahat, Ramat Denya, Givat Masua, Ir Ganim (Jerusalem suburbs)

name: Nitaf
story: A small village located on a mountain ridge, Nitaf was depopulated on April 15, 1948. The Haganah's Harel Brigade captured the village during Operation Nachshon as part of the broader effort to secure the Jerusalem corridor. Its inhabitants were forced to flee, and the village was destroyed. The site remained desolate for many years until the Israeli settlement of Nataf was established there in 1982, appropriating the ancient name of the Palestinian village it replaced.

name: al-Qabu
story: A small village located in the mountainous terrain southwest of Jerusalem, al-Qabu's economy was tied to agriculture. It was captured on October 22, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation ha-Har. This offensive was designed to clear a broad swath of territory, and al-Qabu was one of many villages depopulated during this sweep. Its residents were expelled, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mevo Betar was established on its lands in 1950, and the area is also part of Begin Park.

name: al-Qastal
story: A small but strategically vital village built around a Roman and Crusader fort (Castellum) that commanded the main Jaffa-Jerusalem highway. Al-Qastal became the site of one of the most famous battles of the 1948 war. It was a critical target of Operation Nachshon, the Haganah's first major offensive to break the siege of Jerusalem. It was initially occupied by the Palmach on April 3, 1948. A fierce multi-day battle ensued, during which the charismatic Palestinian commander 'Abd al-Qadir al-Husayni was killed while leading a counter-attack. After its final capture on April 8-9, Palmach units systematically blew up the village's houses, setting a precedent for the destruction of other villages in the corridor. The Israeli settlement of Ma'oz Tziyyon, later merged into Mevasseret Zion, was built on its site.

name: Qalunya
story: A village on the main Jaffa-Jerusalem highway, identified with the Roman settlement of Colonia Amosa and the biblical town of Motza. It was a primary target of Operation Nachshon. On April 11, 1948, after the battle for al-Qastal, Palmach units entered Qalunya and systematically blew up 50 houses, leaving the village ablaze. The remaining inhabitants were ordered out before the destruction. This act of deliberate destruction was one of the first of its kind in the Jerusalem corridor and served as a clear message to other Palestinian communities. The Israeli settlement of Mevasseret Zion was later established on its lands.

name: al-Walaja
story: An agricultural village southwest of Jerusalem, al-Walaja was captured on October 21, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Ha-Har. After its residents were expelled, the village was completely destroyed. The armistice line of 1949 was drawn through its lands, with the village site itself falling on the Israeli side. The villagers rebuilt their community on the Jordanian side of the line, but this 'new' al-Walaja was then occupied by Israel in 1967. The community has since been subjected to continuous land confiscation for the construction of the Apartheid Wall and the expansion of the illegal settlements of Har Gilo and Gilo, strangling the village in a concrete grip.

name: Saris
story: A village perched on a high plateau west of Jerusalem, Saris was attacked and demolished by the Haganah on April 16, 1948, during Operation Nachshon. The Scotsman newspaper reported the destruction of its mosque, a school, and 25 houses. Just before the attack, Haganah chief Israel Galili requested that a settlement be established at Saris 'as soon as possible' for security reasons, revealing the pre-meditated plan of replacement that followed expulsion and destruction. The Israeli settlement of Shoresh was later built on its ruins.

name: Sataf
story: An ancient village built on a steep hillside, Sataf was renowned for its sophisticated agricultural terraces and springs. It was captured on July 13-14, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Dani. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The site was later turned into an Israeli tourist park and recreation area managed by the Jewish National Fund (JNF), which presents the ancient terraces as a generic 'biblical' landscape while completely erasing the memory and heritage of the Palestinian farmers who built and maintained them for centuries.

name: Suba
story: Located on a strategic mountaintop west of Jerusalem, Suba was built within the ruins of the formidable Crusader fortress of Belmont. Its houses were clustered inside the castle's ancient walls. The village was captured on the night of July 12-13, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Dani. According to an Associated Press report at the time, the village was taken 'without combat after a bombardment that drove the Arab defenders' from the strategic heights. The residents who had not already fled the shelling were expelled. The site was later used to establish Kibbutz Tzova, and a forest was planted over much of the village lands, obscuring its history.

name: Abu al-Fadl
story: A small village near the large Sarafand military base, Abu al-Fadl was inhabited by people from various clans, many of whom worked at the base. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Barak, an offensive by the Givati Brigade aimed at clearing Palestinian villages south of Tel Aviv. The operation's orders were to compel the villagers to leave, and those who resisted were to be expelled by force. The village was destroyed, and its lands have since been absorbed into the urban areas of Rishon LeZion and the massive military complex of Tzrifin (formerly Sarafand).

name: Barfiliya
story: A village located on a rocky hill near the town of Lydda, Barfiliya was captured on July 14, 1948, by the 8th Armored Brigade and the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the second phase of the operation after the fall of Lydda and Ramla. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The village lands are now covered by forests planted by the JNF, and the Israeli settlement of Kfar Rut was established nearby.

name: al-Barriyya
story: A small village on the coastal plain whose economy was based on grain, vegetable, and fruit farming. Al-Barriyya was depopulated on July 10, 1948, during Operation Dani, in the period known as the 'Ten Days' of fighting between the first and second truces. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade. While some sources suggest the villagers fled, others indicate they were expelled by the attacking force. After the war, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Azarya was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Bashshit
story: Bashshit was a large village on the southern coastal plain, known for its shrine to a local sage, Nabi Shit (the Prophet Seth). It was depopulated on May 11, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak. The operation's goal was to ethnically cleanse the area around several key roads. The villagers were forced to flee their homes under military assault. The village was later destroyed, though the shrine remains. The Israeli settlements of Aseret, Giv'at Washington, and Kfar Mordechai were established on its lands.

name: Bayt Nabala
story: A large village located on a hilltop, Bayt Nabala was historically significant and had a station on the Jaffa-Lydda railway. It was captured on May 13, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade. The attack was preceded by a mortar barrage. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. A report by an Israeli intelligence officer noted that the destruction of Bayt Nabala and surrounding villages had a 'positive effect' by encouraging the flight of residents from Lydda and Ramla. The settlement of Beit Nehemia was established on its lands.

name: Bayt Shanna
story: A small village in the Latrun salient, Bayt Shanna was depopulated on July 15-16, 1948, during Operation Dani. After the fall of Lydda and Ramla, Israeli forces pushed into the surrounding hills. The village was captured by the Yiftach Brigade. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed as part of the effort to create a depopulated 'no-man's land' in the Latrun area. The site is now covered by a forest planted by the JNF.

name: Bayt Susin
story: Located on a hilltop overlooking the coastal plain, Bayt Susin was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured during Operation Makkabi, which aimed to clear the Jerusalem corridor. The village was attacked, and its residents were forced to flee. The village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ta'oz was established on its lands in 1950. The site is now part of a forest.

name: Bir Ma'in
story: A village located on a rocky plateau, Bir Ma'in was captured on July 15, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the second stage of the operation, expanding control east of Lydda. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mevo Modi'im was later established on its lands.

name: Burj
story: A small village in the Latrun salient, Burj was captured on July 15, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Like other villages in the area (Bayt Shanna, Bir Ma'in), its capture and destruction were part of the plan to ethnically cleanse the Latrun area and widen the corridor to Jerusalem. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The site of the former village is now covered by forest.

name: al-Burj
story: A village located on a strategic hill, al-Burj was captured on October 28-29, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Yoav. After its capture, the village was the scene of a massacre. According to survivor testimonies, Israeli soldiers rounded up the elderly men who had remained, took them to a house, and shot them. The village was then completely destroyed. Its lands are now used by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: Daniyal
story: A village named after a shrine it contained, believed to be the tomb of the Prophet Daniel, Daniyal was captured on July 10, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. The capture was part of the initial assault on the 'Lydda pocket.' The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was destroyed, with the exception of the shrine. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Daniel was established on its lands in 1949, directly appropriating its name.

name: Abu Shusha
story: Situated near the archaeological mound of Tel Gezer, Abu Shusha was a village whose inhabitants farmed grain, vegetables, and fruit. It was captured on May 14, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Makkabi. A massacre occurred in the village after its capture. According to Israeli military archives and survivor accounts, soldiers killed dozens of villagers, including women. The remaining population was expelled. The village was then completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ameilim, later renamed Karmei Yosef, was established on its land.

name: Ajanjul
story: A small village in the Ramle sub-district, Ajanjul's existence was tied to the land and agriculture. It was depopulated during the summer of 1948, likely in July during the widespread Israeli offensives in the area, such as Operation Dani or An-Far. The specific details of its capture are sparse, as it was one of many small communities swept away during the major military operations. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was subsequently erased. Its lands were later absorbed by the state.

name: 'Abisiyya
story: A small village in the northern Hula Valley, 'Abisiyya was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The operation's goal was to ethnically cleanse the entire eastern Galilee of its Palestinian population. The villagers were forced to flee, many seeking refuge in Syria. The village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Lehavot HaBashan was established on its lands.

name: Akbara
story: An ancient village south of Safad, Akbara was depopulated on May 9, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. Palmach forces captured the village and expelled its inhabitants. In a unique and cruel twist, some of the villagers were later rounded up by Israeli authorities and forcibly resettled in Akbara, which was turned into a ghetto for internally displaced Palestinians from other villages. The original village houses were destroyed in 1950 and the residents were moved into new, shoddier houses built by the state, where they remain today under surveillance.

name: 'Ammuqa
story: A village located on a mountainside near Safad, 'Ammuqa was known for its olive and fruit groves. It was captured on May 24, 1948, by the Palmach's First Battalion during Operation Yiftach. The villagers had a reputation for being heavily armed and were expected to put up resistance, but they were ultimately driven out. After the expulsion, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Amuka was established on its site in 1980, appropriating the ancient name.

name: al-'Awayiziyya
story: A small village in the northern Hula Valley, al-'Awayiziyya was depopulated on May 25, 1948, during the final stages of Operation Yiftach. The operation's success in 'clearing' the Galilee was contingent on the removal of all Palestinian communities, large and small. The villagers were forced to flee, most likely across the border into Syria. The village was then destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Lehavot HaBashan.

name: Ayn al-Zaytun
story: A village just north of Safad, Ayn al-Zaytun was the site of a brutal massacre that served as a prelude to the fall of the city. On May 1-2, 1948, Palmach forces attacked the village as part of Operation Yiftach. After the village surrendered, dozens of unarmed men, estimated between 30 and 70, were taken prisoner, tied up, and executed in a nearby valley. The news of the massacre was deliberately spread to terrorize the inhabitants of Safad, contributing to its fall a few days later. The remaining villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed.

name: al-Butayha
story: Al-Butayha was a large area of Bedouin settlement on the fertile plains northeast of the Sea of Galilee. The area was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh ('Broom'), a precursor to Operation Yiftach. The goal was to clear the Bedouin tribes from the area between the Jordan River and the Sea of Galilee. The residents were shelled and forced to flee into Syria. Their lands were subsequently taken over by several Israeli settlements, including Almagor.

name: al-Buwayziyya
story: A village located in the fertile Hula Valley, al-Buwayziyya's economy was centered on agriculture. It was captured on May 11, 1948, by the Palmach's First Battalion during Operation Yiftach. The operation was a systematic campaign to ethnically cleanse the entire eastern Galilee. The villagers were forced to flee their homes under military assault, with most seeking refuge in Syria. The village was then completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Neot Mordechai was later established on its lands.

name: Dallata
story: A village situated on a rocky slope near Safad, Dallata was known for its olive groves and was the site of an ancient synagogue. It was depopulated in early May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. Palmach commander Yigal Allon's strategy was to create a wave of panic through psychological warfare and exemplary attacks, such as the nearby 'Ayn al-Zaytun massacre. The residents of Dallata fled in fear of a similar fate. The village was later completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Dalton was established on its lands in 1950, appropriating its ancient name.

name: al-Dawwara
story: Al-Dawwara was a village in the Hula Valley, its population primarily engaged in farming. It was captured on May 25, 1948, by the Palmach during the final stages of Operation Yiftach. The operation's complete success depended on the removal of every last Palestinian community from the 'finger of Galilee.' The inhabitants were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Amir and Sde Nechemya were established on its lands.

name: Dayshum
story: A large village in the mountains of the Upper Galilee, Dayshum was captured on October 30, 1948, during Operation Hiram. After its capture by the Sheva' (7th) Brigade, the village was the site of a brutal massacre. According to Israeli military archives, soldiers murdered between 70 and 80 civilians, including women and children, in one of the houses. The remaining villagers were then expelled, with many forced across the border into Lebanon. The village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Dishon was established on its lands in 1953.

name: al-Dirbashiyya
story: A small village in the Hula Valley, al-Dirbashiyya's inhabitants were farmers. It was depopulated on May 25, 1948, during the final sweep of Operation Yiftach. The Palmach's offensive systematically cleared the valley, forcing residents to flee in terror toward Syria. The village was then destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the nearby Israeli settlement of Gonen.

name: al-Dirdara
story: Meaning 'the ash tree,' al-Dirdara was a small village in the Hula Valley. It was captured by Palmach forces in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The inhabitants were expelled from their homes, and the village was destroyed. In a pattern common to the Hula Valley, the lands of the former village were later taken over by a nearby Israeli kibbutz, in this case, Hulata.

name: Fara
story: A village located on a slope overlooking a wadi, Fara was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by the Palmach's First Battalion during Operation Yiftach. The psychological warfare campaign, including the 'Ayn al-Zaytun massacre and the fall of Safad, led the villagers to flee in fear for their lives. The village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Amirim was established near the site in 1950.

name: Fir'im
story: A village situated on a hillside near Safad, Fir'im was captured on May 2, 1948, by the Palmach during Operation Yiftach. It was one of the villages attacked in the operation's opening stages to terrorize the population of the surrounding area and of Safad itself. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Hatzor HaGlilit was established on its lands in the 1950s.

name: Ghuraba
story: Ghuraba was a small village on the western edge of the Hula Valley. It was depopulated on April 22, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. Palmach forces overran the village as they secured the roads and approaches to Safad. The inhabitants were forced to flee, and their homes were destroyed. The site of the village is now farmland, cultivated by the Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaYarden.

name: Ghubatiyya
story: A small village in the Golan Heights, which was part of the Safad sub-district during the Mandate. Ghubatiyya was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. Its location in the far northeastern corner of Palestine made it an early target for clearance. Its inhabitants were forced to flee into Syria, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later declared part of a nature reserve by Israel.

name: Harrawi
story: A small village in the northern Hula Valley, Harrawi was depopulated on May 25, 1948. It was captured by the Palmach during the final sweep of Operation Yiftach that cleared the entire 'finger of Galilee' of its Palestinian residents. The villagers were expelled, most likely into Lebanon or Syria, and their homes were demolished. The lands of the former village are now cultivated by the Israeli settlement of Kfar Szold.

name: Hunin
story: Hunin was a large and strategically important Shi'a Muslim village in the Upper Galilee, built around a major Crusader fortress. The village was handed over to Haganah forces by the British on April 14, 1948. Initially, the villagers were promised they could stay, but in early June, they were systematically expelled. Palmach soldiers forced the villagers out at gunpoint, driving them across the border into Lebanon. The village was later completely destroyed, with the exception of the fortress ruins. The Israeli settlement of Misgav Am was established on its lands.

name: Jahula
story: Jahula was a village located on the slopes of the mountains overlooking the Hula Valley. It was captured on May 1, 1948, by the Palmach's First Battalion during Operation Yiftach. The capture of Jahula was part of the initial phase aimed at isolating Safad. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were later demolished. The Israeli settlement of Yessud HaMa'ala, established nearby in the 1880s, expanded its agricultural lands over the site.

name: al-Ja'una
story: An ancient village on the slopes of Mount Canaan, overlooking the Hula Valley, al-Ja'una's population was predominantly Muslim. The Zionist colony of Rosh Pinna was established near it in the 1880s, leading to decades of friction. The village was depopulated in April 1948, shortly after the Deir Yassin massacre. Haganah forces mortared the village, and its inhabitants fled in terror. Rosh Pinna then expanded and completely absorbed the village, taking over its houses and lands in a direct act of colonization.

name: Jubb Yusuf
story: Jubb Yusuf was a village of great significance in Islamic tradition, believed to be the site of the well into which the prophet Joseph was cast by his brothers. The village, with its historic khan (caravanserai), was captured on May 4, 1948, by the Palmach during Operation Yiftach. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was destroyed, though the khan and tomb remain. The Israeli settlement of Ami'ad was established on its lands in 1946 and expanded after the village's destruction.

name: Kafr Bir'im
story: A large and ancient Maronite Christian village in the Upper Galilee, Kafr Bir'im was known for its beautiful church and the ruins of a magnificent ancient synagogue. It was captured without a fight on October 31, 1948, during Operation Hiram. In November, the Israeli army ordered the villagers to evacuate for two weeks 'for security reasons,' promising them they could return. This was a lie. The villagers were never allowed to return. They became internally displaced citizens and waged a decades-long legal battle for their right of return, which the Israeli Supreme Court affirmed but the military refused to implement. In 1953, the village was bombed by the Israeli air force and completely destroyed, except for its church, as a final act to prevent the villagers' return. The settlement of Bar'am was built on its lands.

name: al-Khalisa
story: A large village and the commercial center of the Hula Valley, al-Khalisa was a key target of Operation Yiftach. On May 11, 1948, Palmach forces shelled the village, and its leaders were told that they would 'suffer the fate of 'Ayn al-Zaytun' if they did not leave. Terrified by the threat of a massacre, the entire population fled into Lebanon. The village was then occupied and destroyed. The Israeli town of Kiryat Shmona was built on its ruins, its name ('Town of the Eight') commemorating Zionist fighters while erasing the memory of the Palestinian town it replaced.

name: Khan al-Duwayr
story: A village in the northern Hula Valley, Khan al-Duwayr was depopulated on May 25, 1948, during the final sweep of Operation Yiftach. The Palmach's systematic campaign left no Palestinian community standing in the region. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Szold, established in 1942, expanded its agricultural lands over the site of the former village.

name: Khirbat al-Muntar
story: A small village in the Hula Valley, Khirbat al-Muntar was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. Its capture was part of the broad offensive to clear the entire region. The inhabitants were forced to flee, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the agricultural holdings of the nearby Israeli settlement of Kfar Blum.

name: Khirbat Karraza
story: Located on the site of the ancient Jewish town of Chorazin, mentioned in the New Testament, Khirbat Karraza was a small Palestinian village. It was captured on May 4, 1948, by the Palmach during Operation Matateh ('Broom'), a precursor to Yiftach. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Korazim was established nearby, and the ancient ruins were turned into a national archaeological park, erasing the history of the modern Palestinian community that had lived there.

name: Khiyam al-Walid
story: A village in the northern Hula Valley, Khiyam al-Walid was known for its flour mills powered by the nearby river. It was captured by the Palmach on May 1, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. The villagers were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Lehavot HaBashan was later established on its lands.

name: Kirad al-Baqqara
story: A Bedouin village of the Kirad tribes, located in the Hula Valley, Kirad al-Baqqara was depopulated on April 22, 1948. It was captured during Operation Yiftach's initial phase, which aimed to secure the area west of the Jordan River. The inhabitants were expelled from their homes and lands. The Israeli settlement of Gadot was established on the site in 1949.

name: Kirad al-Ghannama
story: The second of the Kirad Bedouin villages in the Hula Valley, Kirad al-Ghannama was also depopulated on April 22, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. The expulsion of the Kirad tribes was a key objective in 'cleansing' the valley. The villagers were forced to flee, and their settlement was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ayelet HaShahar, established earlier, expanded its lands to cover the site.

name: Lazzaza
story: Lazzaza was a small village located at the northern tip of Palestine. It was one of the first villages to be depopulated in the Hula Valley, captured on April 21, 1948, during the early stages of Operation Yiftach. The Palmach forces attacked the village, forcing its residents to flee into Lebanon. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Beit Hillel was established on its lands.

name: Madahil
story: A small village on the western shore of the Hula Lake, Madahil was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The systematic clearing of the Hula basin by Palmach forces left no community untouched. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The lands of the former village are now part of the Hula Nature Reserve, another instance where 'nature preservation' was used to obscure and finalize the ethnic cleansing of the area.

name: al-Malikiyya
story: A Shi'a Muslim village located on the Lebanese border, al-Malikiyya was a key strategic prize. It changed hands multiple times in fierce fighting. It was first captured by the Palmach on May 15, 1948, during Operation Yiftach, but was retaken by the Lebanese army. It was finally captured by Israeli forces on October 30 during Operation Hiram. After its final capture, its entire population was expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Malkiya was established on its lands in 1949, directly appropriating the village's name.

name: al-Manshiyya
story: A small village in the Hula Valley, al-Manshiyya was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The operation's systematic sweep of the valley ensured that all Palestinian communities were removed to create a 'cleansed' territory. The inhabitants of al-Manshiyya were forced to flee, and their homes were subsequently demolished. The lands of the former village were taken over by the Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaYarden.

name: al-Mansura
story: Al-Mansura was a village in the Upper Galilee, west of the main road to Safad. It was captured late in the war, during Operation Hiram, on October 30, 1948. The operation was designed to conquer the entire Galilee region. Following its capture by Israeli forces, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Netu'a was established nearby in 1966, and its lands were assigned to other existing settlements.

name: Marus
story: A small village located north of Safad, Marus was depopulated on May 2, 1948, during the early stages of Operation Yiftach. The strategy of the operation relied on creating panic among the civilian population through exemplary attacks and psychological warfare. The villagers of Marus fled in fear of the advancing Palmach forces. The village was then occupied and later destroyed. The site is now covered by a forest planted by the JNF.

name: Mays al-Jabal
story: A small village situated right on the Lebanese border, Mays al-Jabal was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by Palmach forces during Operation Yiftach. Given its location, its inhabitants were forced to flee directly into Lebanon. The village was subsequently destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Yiftach, named after the very military operation that led to the village's destruction and the expulsion of its people.

name: Mughr al-Khayt
story: Mughr al-Khayt was a village inhabited by Bedouins of the 'Arab al-Zubayd tribe. It was located in the Hula Valley. The village was depopulated on May 2, 1948, by the Palmach during Operation Yiftach. The operation specifically targeted Bedouin communities in the valley for expulsion. After the residents were driven out, their village was destroyed. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Rosh Pinna.

name: al-Na'ima
story: A village in the fertile Hula Valley, al-Na'ima was known for its agriculture. It was captured on May 14, 1948, by the Palmach during Operation Yiftach. The capture of al-Na'ima was part of the systematic campaign to clear the entire valley of Palestinians. Its inhabitants were expelled, with most fleeing to Syria. The village was then completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Neot Mordechai and Kfar Blum were established on its lands.

name: Qabba'a
story: Qabba'a was a village in the mountains of the Upper Galilee, known for its figs, grapes, and olives. It was captured late in the war, on October 30, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Hiram. Following its capture, the villagers were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed by Israeli forces. The site is now overgrown with trees planted by the JNF, a common method of erasing Palestinian history.

name: Qadas
story: An ancient village with a history stretching back to the Canaanites, Qadas was located on the Lebanese border. It was captured on May 14, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. The capture was preceded by shelling to terrorize the inhabitants. After the villagers fled or were expelled, mostly into Lebanon, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Yiftach was established nearby, and the archaeological site of Tel Kedesh is located on its lands, focusing on ancient history while ignoring the modern Palestinian village that was destroyed.

name: Qaddita
story: Qaddita was a small village located on a high slope west of Safad. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The fall of Safad itself on May 10-11 created a wave of panic, causing the inhabitants of smaller surrounding villages like Qaddita to flee for their lives. The village was then occupied and later destroyed. An Israeli artist colony was later established at the site, with some of the new structures incorporating the stones from the destroyed Palestinian homes.

name: al-Ras al-Ahmar
story: Meaning 'the red peak,' al-Ras al-Ahmar was a village situated on a volcanic hill. It was captured late in the war, on October 30, 1948, by the 7th Brigade during Operation Hiram. After its capture, the villagers were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. Today, the area is a military firing zone, and the land is used for grazing by the settlement of Kerem Ben Zimra, established on the lands of the nearby depopulated village of al-Ras al-Ahmar.

name: Sabalan
story: A small Druze village in the Upper Galilee, Sabalan was known for its shrine to a Druze prophet, Nabi Sabalan. It was captured by the Israeli army during Operation Hiram in October 1948. Unlike its Muslim and Christian neighbors, the Druze residents of Sabalan were not expelled, due to a complex and controversial alliance forged between the emerging Israeli state and some leaders of the Druze community. The village continues to exist today.

name: Safsaf
story: Safsaf was a village in the Upper Galilee. It was captured on October 29, 1948, during Operation Hiram. After the villagers surrendered, Israeli soldiers from the 7th Brigade carried out a horrific massacre. They tied up and shot between 50 and 70 men, threw their bodies in a well, and raped several women and girls. The remaining villagers were then expelled. The massacre at Safsaf was one of several that occurred during Operation Hiram, designed to terrorize the population and ensure their permanent removal. The Israeli settlement of Sifsufa was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Saliha
story: A village located on the Lebanese border, Saliha was captured on October 30, 1948, during Operation Hiram. It was the site of another brutal massacre by Israeli forces. After the village surrendered, soldiers rounded up approximately 94 men, herded them into a house, and murdered them by blowing up the building. The rest of the villagers were expelled into Lebanon. The massacre at Saliha, like those at Safsaf and al-Dawayima, was a calculated act of terror aimed at ensuring the ethnic cleansing of the region. The Israeli settlement of Yir'on was established on its lands.

name: al-Salihiyya
story: Al-Salihiyya was a village in the northern Hula Valley. It was captured by the Palmach on May 25, 1948, during the final phase of Operation Yiftach. The operation's goal of clearing the 'finger of Galilee' was ruthlessly pursued. The inhabitants of al-Salihiyya were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Kfar Blum.

name: al-Sammu'i
story: A village located in the mountainous region of the Upper Galilee, al-Sammu'i was captured on October 30, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Hiram. After its capture, its residents were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed by Israeli forces. The site is now a forested area, and the Israeli settlement of Kfar Shamai was established nearby, with its agricultural lands covering the former village site.

name: al-Sanbariyya
story: A small village in the northern Hula Valley, al-Sanbariyya was depopulated on May 25, 1948. It was captured by the Palmach during the final sweep of Operation Yiftach. The offensive left no Palestinian community untouched in its quest to secure the region. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Ma'ayan Baruch was established nearby and took over its lands.

name: Sa'sa'
story: Sa'sa' was a village in the Upper Galilee that suffered two major attacks. The first was a massacre on February 15, 1948, when Palmach commandos raided the village at night, blew up over 20 houses over the heads of their inhabitants, and killed around 60 people, many of them women and children. This was a calculated act of terror. The village was finally captured and its remaining inhabitants expelled on October 30, 1948, during Operation Hiram. The village was then completely destroyed. Kibbutz Sasa was built on its ruins in 1949.

name: al-Shawka al-Tahta
story: Meaning 'the lower thorn,' this village was located near the Jordan River. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The systematic clearing of the area by Palmach forces led to the expulsion of its residents. The village was then destroyed. Its lands were later absorbed by the Israeli settlement of Ayelet HaShahar.

name: al-'Abidiyya
story: A village located on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee, al-'Abidiyya was depopulated on March 3, 1948. It was one of the first villages in the Tiberias district to be ethnically cleansed. Haganah forces attacked the village, forcing its residents to flee. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kvutzat Kinneret, established earlier, expanded onto its lands.

name: 'Awlam
story: An ancient village with a history dating back to the Canaanites, 'Awlam was located southwest of Tiberias. It was captured on April 22, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The capture was part of the operations that followed the fall of Tiberias, aimed at clearing the city's hinterland. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Kisch was established on its lands.

name: Ghuwayr Abu Shusha
story: A village on the northwestern shore of the Sea of Galilee, Ghuwayr Abu Shusha was known for its vegetable and grain cultivation. It was depopulated on April 28, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The attack was part of the final clearing of the Tiberias area. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The lands of the former village were taken over by the nearby Israeli settlements of Genosar and Migdal.

name: Haddatha
story: A village located in the hills west of the Sea of Galilee, Haddatha was captured on May 12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. The operation aimed to clear the areas between Tiberias and Baysan. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Kisch was established nearby and uses the former village's lands for agriculture.

name: al-Hamma
story: Known since Roman times for its hot mineral springs, al-Hamma was a spa town in the Yarmuk River valley. It was captured by Haganah forces on May 18, 1948. The area became a demilitarized zone under the 1949 armistice agreement with Syria, but Israel violated the agreement and expelled the remaining villagers in 1949. The village was destroyed, and the spa was developed into the Israeli tourist resort of Hamat Gader.

name: al-Majdal
story: An ancient village on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee, al-Majdal is identified with the biblical town of Magdala, the home of Mary Magdalene. In 1948, it was a small fishing village. It was captured on April 22, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Migdal was established nearby, appropriating the ancient name, and a tourist hotel was built on the village lands.

name: al-Manara
story: A small village in the hills west of the Sea of Galilee, al-Manara was depopulated on April 21, 1948. It was captured by the Golani Brigade as part of the operations to clear the hinterland of Tiberias after the city's fall. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Kama, a Circassian town, expanded its agricultural lands over the former village site.

name: al-Manshiyya
story: Al-Manshiyya was a small village located near the western shore of the Sea of Galilee. It was depopulated on April 18, 1948, during the battle for Tiberias. As Haganah forces advanced and the city fell, the inhabitants of smaller surrounding villages like al-Manshiyya fled in terror. The village was then occupied and destroyed. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli city of Tiberias as it expanded.

name: al-Mansura
story: A village in the Tiberias sub-district, al-Mansura was depopulated in April 1948. Its fate was tied to the fall of Tiberias and the subsequent clearing operations by the Golani Brigade. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished to prevent any return. The lands of the former village are now used for agriculture by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: Nasir al-Din
story: A small village on a hilltop overlooking Tiberias, Nasir al-Din was the site of a brutal massacre that precipitated the fall of the city. On the night of April 11-12, 1948, Palmach and Golani Brigade soldiers infiltrated the village. They blew up houses and shot inhabitants as they fled. A number of villagers were taken prisoner and then executed. The massacre was a deliberate act of psychological warfare; survivors were sent into Tiberias to spread terror, which contributed significantly to the city's surrender a week later. The village was completely destroyed.

name: Nimrin
story: A village located in the hills west of the Sea of Galilee, Nimrin was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by the Golani Brigade during the operations that followed the fall of Tiberias. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was destroyed. Its lands are now part of the Arbel National Park and Nature Reserve.

name: al-Nuqayb
story: A small village situated on the northeastern shore of the Sea of Galilee, al-Nuqayb was captured on May 15, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. Its capture was part of the effort to secure the entire shoreline of the lake. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Ein Gev, established in 1937, expanded its lands to cover the site of the former village.

name: Samakh
story: Samakh was a large and strategically important town at the southern tip of the Sea of Galilee, serving as a major transportation hub with a railway station. It was captured on April 28, 1948, by the Golani Brigade after a fierce battle with local defenders and the Arab Liberation Army. The fall of Samakh was a major blow and secured the entire southern part of the lake for Zionist forces. The inhabitants were expelled, and the town was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Ma'agan and Masada were established on its lands.

name: al-Samakiyya
story: A fishing village on the northeastern shore of the Sea of Galilee, al-Samakiyya was home to the 'Arab al-Shamalina Bedouin tribe. It was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh ('Broom'), an offensive designed to clear the area between the Jordan River and the lake. The villagers were forced to flee, many into Syria. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kafr Aqab was briefly established on the site before being abandoned.

name: al-Samra
story: A village on the eastern shore of the Sea of Galilee, al-Samra was depopulated in March 1948. It was one of the first villages in the area to be cleared by Haganah forces. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of HaOn was established on its lands in 1949. The area was declared a demilitarized zone under the 1949 armistice, but Israel retained control and colonized the land.

name: al-Shajara
story: An ancient village with a history going back to the Canaanites, al-Shajara was located in the Lower Galilee. It was the site of a major and prolonged battle. It was finally captured on May 6, 1948, by the Golani Brigade after fierce resistance from local militia and the Arab Liberation Army. The capture of al-Shajara was a key victory for the Haganah in the region. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ilaniya, which had been founded nearby, expanded onto its lands.

name: Tabariyyah (Tiberias)
story: An ancient city on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee, Tiberias had a mixed population of about 5,000 Palestinians and 6,000 Jews. On April 18, 1948, after a week-long battle and the massacre at the nearby village of Nasir al-Din, the Palestinian population surrendered. The British army, which was still officially in control, facilitated the complete evacuation of the Palestinian residents, transporting them by truck and boat to Transjordan and Lebanon. Tiberias was the first major mixed city to be entirely ethnically cleansed of its Palestinian population, setting a precedent for the subsequent fall of Haifa and Jaffa.

name: al-'Ubaydiyya
story: Located south of the Sea of Galilee, al-'Ubaydiyya was known for its hot springs and ancient ruins. The village was captured on March 3, 1948, in an early attack by the Golani Brigade. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Beit Zera was established on its lands in 1927 and later expanded over the village site.

name: al-Wa'ra al-Sawda'
story: Meaning 'the black rugged land,' this was a Bedouin settlement of the 'Arab al-Mawasi tribe. It was located north of the Sea of Galilee. The settlement was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh ('Broom'). The operation was designed to clear all the Bedouin communities from the area. The residents were forcibly expelled, and their encampment was destroyed. The lands were later taken over by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: Bayyarat Hannun
story: A small community on the coastal plain, Bayyarat Hannun was known for its citrus groves ('bayyarat'). It was depopulated on March 3, 1948. Haganah forces implemented a policy of clearing Palestinian communities from the coastal plain to create a secure, contiguous Zionist territory. The villagers were forced out, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ganot Hadar was later established on its lands.

name: Fardisya
story: A small village in the coastal plain, Fardisya was depopulated on April 1, 1948. It was captured by the Alexandroni Brigade during the coastal clearing operations. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Fardesiyya was established on its lands, directly appropriating the village's name.

name: Ghabat Kafr Sur
story: Meaning 'the forest of Kafr Sur,' this area was a collection of agricultural lands and homes belonging to the residents of the nearby village of Kafr Sur. It was depopulated in May 1948. As Zionist forces advanced and secured the coastal plain, the residents were unable to access their lands and were forced to abandon them. The area was taken over by the Israeli settlement of Geulim.

name: Jaljuliya
story: An ancient village with a history stretching back to the Roman period, Jaljuliya was located on the plain east of Jaffa. Unlike most other villages in the area, Jaljuliya was not depopulated during the 1948 war. It remained on the Arab side of the armistice line. However, in the 1949 armistice agreement with Jordan, it was transferred to Israeli control as part of a land swap. The residents were allowed to stay, and it remains a Palestinian town in Israel today, though it lost much of its land.

name: Kafr Saba
story: An ancient village with a long history, Kafr Saba was located on the coastal plain. It was captured by the Alexandroni Brigade on May 13, 1948. The attack on the village was part of a broader offensive to secure the area and remove its Palestinian population. The villagers were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli city of Kfar Saba, which had been founded nearby, expanded to completely cover the site of the former Palestinian village.

name: al-Majdal
story: Al-Majdal was a large, ancient, and historically significant Palestinian town, a major center for weaving and commerce. It was captured by Israeli forces on November 4, 1948, during Operation Yoav. Initially, its 10,000 residents were not expelled but were concentrated into a ghettoized area surrounded by barbed wire. Over the next two years, they were subjected to a campaign of harassment and coercion to force them to leave. By 1950, all of the original Palestinian inhabitants had been expelled to Gaza. The town was then settled by Jewish immigrants and renamed Ashkelon, a direct act of demographic replacement.

name: al-Mas'udiyya
story: A small village near the coast, al-Mas'udiyya was depopulated in April 1948. It was one of many villages cleared by the Haganah during the systematic ethnic cleansing of the coastal plain. The villagers were forced to flee their homes, which were then destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Sde Warburg.

name: Misir
story: Misir was a small village whose inhabitants were originally from Egypt, hence its name. It was depopulated in November 1948. Although it lay within the territory allotted to the Arab state in the UN partition plan, it was captured by Israeli forces after the second truce. Its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Meiser was established on its ruins, appropriating the village's name.

name: Qaqun
story: A large and historically important village, Qaqun was built around a Crusader and Mamluk fortress. It was a major agricultural center. The village was attacked on June 4, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade. The attack was preceded by a heavy artillery barrage. After a fierce battle in which the villagers and local Iraqi volunteers put up a strong defense, the village was captured. The inhabitants were expelled, and the village was systematically destroyed, with the exception of the fortress. The Israeli settlement of Gan Yoshiya was established on its lands.

name: Raml Zayta
story: A small village on the coastal plain, Raml Zayta ('the sand of Zayta') was an offshoot of the larger village of Zayta. It was depopulated in April 1948 during the coastal clearing operations. Haganah forces swept through the area, forcing the inhabitants of smaller communities to flee. The village was destroyed, and its lands were later taken over by the Israeli city of Hadera.

name: Tabrat
story: A small village located near the city of Tiberias, Tabrat was depopulated on April 18, 1948. Its fate was directly tied to the fall of Tiberias. As Haganah forces captured the main city, the residents of nearby smaller villages like Tabrat fled in fear of the fighting and potential massacres. The village was subsequently destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the expanding city of Tiberias.

name: Umm Khalid
story: A large and ancient coastal village, Umm Khalid was strategically located near the sea. It was captured on March 20, 1948, in an early attack by the Haganah. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli city of Netanya, which had been founded nearby in 1929, expanded to completely engulf the site of the former Palestinian village, erasing a center of coastal life that had existed for centuries.

name: Wadi al-Hawarith (North)
story: Wadi al-Hawarith was a large Bedouin area along the coast that was the subject of a famous land dispute in the 1930s when the land was sold by a distant landlord to the Jewish National Fund. The Bedouin farmers who had lived there for generations resisted their eviction fiercely. In 1948, the final depopulation occurred. On May 15, Haganah forces captured the northern part of the area, expelling its inhabitants and destroying their encampments. The Israeli settlement of Geuley Teiman was established on their lands.

name: Wadi al-Hawarith (South)
story: The southern part of the Wadi al-Hawarith Bedouin area shared the fate of its northern counterpart. After years of resisting Zionist colonization efforts, the remaining inhabitants were expelled by Haganah forces on May 15, 1948, during the systematic clearing of the coastal plain. The destruction of their community ended a long chapter of Palestinian steadfastness against colonial encroachment. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Vitkin was built on these lands, erasing the presence of the Bedouin community.

name: 'Amqa
story: An ancient village in the Western Galilee, 'Amqa was captured on July 10-11, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Dekel. Most of its inhabitants fled during the assault, but a small number remained. In a pattern repeated elsewhere, the Israeli army used the village to house refugees from other destroyed villages for a time, before expelling everyone, including the original inhabitants, in early 1949. The village was then completely destroyed, with only its school and mosque remaining. The Israeli settlement of Amka was established on its lands in 1949.

name: 'Arab al-Samniyya
story: A Bedouin village in the hills of the Western Galilee, 'Arab al-Samniyya was captured on October 30, 1948, by the Sheva' (7th) Brigade during Operation Hiram. The operation was designed to conquer the entire Galilee. Following its capture, the villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ya'ara was established on their lands in 1950.

name: al-Birwa
story: A significant Palestinian Arab village with a history stretching back to the Roman period, al-Birwa was known for its olive groves, two schools, a mosque, and a church. It gained cultural prominence as the birthplace of the Palestinian national poet, Mahmoud Darwish. In early June 1948, the village was initially occupied by Zionist forces during Operation Dekel. Displaying remarkable steadfastness, the villagers, with support from the Arab Liberation Army, staged a counter-attack and recaptured their homes for two days to harvest their crops. However, a much larger Israeli military assault followed, forcing a final, permanent expulsion of all inhabitants. The village was then almost entirely razed to the ground, with the Jewish National Fund (JNF) planting forests over the ruins. The settlements of Yas'ur and Ahihud were established on its lands, erasing a center of Palestinian life and culture.

name: al-Damun
story: Situated on the Acre plain, al-Damun was a village with deep historical roots, containing ancient architectural remains and the shrine of the prophet Dhu al-Kifl, mentioned in the Qur'an. Its economy was primarily agricultural, focused on grains, olives, and melons, supplemented by the weaving of mats from nearby rushes. On July 15-16, 1948, during the second stage of Operation Dekel, the village was attacked by the Israeli army's Sheva' (7th) Brigade. Already demoralized by the fall of the major cities of Acre and Nazareth, many villagers fled under the initial heavy shelling. Those who remained were forcibly expelled by the occupying troops. Following the expulsion, Israeli forces systematically destroyed the village, leaving only a few stone houses and the shrine as desolate reminders of a vibrant community.
israeli_settlement: None on village site; lands used by Yas'ur

name: Dayr al-Qassi
story: A large Christian village in the Upper Galilee, Dayr al-Qassi was captured on October 30, 1948, during Operation Hiram. Its inhabitants were not immediately expelled, but were subjected to harassment and intimidation. In May 1949, they were forcibly transferred to the nearby village of al-Bassa, and from there expelled to refugee camps. The village was then completely destroyed, with the exception of its church. The Israeli settlement of Elkosh was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Ghabisiyya
story: A village in the Western Galilee, al-Ghabisiyya was depopulated on May 21, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. The villagers fled after hearing of the fall of Acre and the surrounding villages. In an extremely rare case, some villagers were allowed to return in 1951, but were then re-expelled by the Israeli military. After a long legal battle, the Israeli Supreme Court ruled that the villagers had a right to their land, but the military government refused to allow them to return and declared the village a closed military zone, a stark example of the Israeli judiciary being overruled by the military.

name: Iqrit
story: A prosperous Maronite Christian village in the Upper Galilee, Iqrit surrendered without a fight to the Israeli army on October 31, 1948. In November, the army ordered the villagers to leave their homes for two weeks for 'security reasons,' promising them they could return. This was a deliberate deception. The villagers were never allowed to return, becoming internally displaced citizens. They waged a decades-long legal battle, and in 1951, the Israeli Supreme Court recognized their right to return. In response, on Christmas Day 1951, the Israeli army completely destroyed the village by shelling it, leaving only the church standing.
