The case of Iqrit, like that of Kafr Bir'im, is a landmark example of the state's use of military force to defy its own judiciary and prevent the return of Palestinian refugees.

name: Khirbat Iribbin
story: A small village in the mountains of the Western Galilee, Khirbat Iribbin was depopulated on October 31, 1948, during Operation Hiram. It was captured by the Oded Brigade as it swept through the area. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Adamit was established on its lands in 1958.

name: Khirbat Jiddin
story: Built around a large Crusader fortress known as Judin, this village was depopulated in two stages. Some residents fled after the fall of Acre in May 1948, while the rest were expelled when the village was captured on October 31 during Operation Hiram. The village was destroyed, but the fortress remains. The Israeli settlement of Yehi'am, which was established nearby in 1946, took over its lands.

name: al-Kabri
story: A large village in the Western Galilee known for its abundant springs, al-Kabri was captured on May 21, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. The capture was followed by a massacre. According to Haganah sources, soldiers from the Carmeli Brigade killed a number of villagers and prisoners. After the expulsion of the inhabitants, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Kabri and Ein Ya'akov were established on its lands.

name: Kuwaykat
story: A village on the coastal plain of Acre, Kuwaykat was known for its olive groves and was the birthplace of the scholar and poet Sheikh 'Abdullah al-Jahiz. The village was attacked on July 9, 1948, during the 'Ten Days' battles. It was shelled by Israeli forces, causing many to flee. After its capture, the remaining villagers were rounded up and expelled. The village was completely destroyed, and the Israeli settlement of Beit HaEmek was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Manshiyya
story: A small village located just south of the city of Acre, al-Manshiyya was depopulated on May 14, 1948. Its fate was directly tied to the fall of Acre during Operation Ben-Ami. As Haganah forces advanced on the city, the inhabitants of the smaller surrounding villages fled in terror. The village was then completely destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the expanding city of Acre.

name: al-Mansura
story: A village located in the mountains of the Western Galilee, al-Mansura was captured on October 31, 1948, during Operation Hiram. Its residents were not immediately expelled but remained until 1950, when they were forcibly removed by the Israeli army. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Netu'a was established nearby, and a military base was also built on its lands.

name: Mi'ar
story: A village in the hills of the Lower Galilee, Mi'ar was known for its history of resistance against Zionist colonization. It was captured on July 15, 1948, during Operation Dekel. The capture was followed by the expulsion of its inhabitants. The village was completely destroyed, and the Israeli settlement of Ya'ad was established on its lands in 1974.

name: al-Nabi Rubin
story: A small village in the Upper Galilee, al-Nabi Rubin was named after a shrine it contained. It was captured on October 31, 1948, during Operation Hiram. Following its capture by Israeli forces, its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Even Menachem settlement.

name: al-Nahr
story: A village located near the coast, al-Nahr was part of a cluster with the villages of al-Kabri and al-Tall. It was captured on May 21, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. Following the capture of the area, a massacre was carried out at al-Kabri, which likely terrorized the residents of al-Nahr into fleeing. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kabri was established on its lands.

name: al-Ruways
story: A small village on the Acre plain, al-Ruways was depopulated on July 16, 1948. It was captured by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Dekel. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The site of the former village is now part of an industrial zone, and its lands are used by the settlement of Yas'ur.

name: al-Sumayriyya
story: A coastal village north of Acre, known to Crusaders as 'Someleria,' al-Sumayriyya's economy was based on agriculture and stone quarrying. It was captured on May 14, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. While Israeli sources claim villagers fled, Palestinian sources describe heavy fighting. A New York Times photo showed extensive wreckage from 'Jewish demolition squads.' By June 1948, the JNF had begun leveling the village. The Israeli settlements of Lochamey HaGeta'ot and Shomrat were established on its lands.

name: Suruh
story: A village in the mountains of the Western Galilee, Suruh was captured on October 31, 1948, during Operation Hiram. Following its capture by the Oded Brigade, its residents were expelled, with many forced across the border into Lebanon. The village was later completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Goren was established on its lands in 1950.

name: al-Tall
story: Also known as Khirbat al-Tall, this village was part of the cluster that included al-Nahr and al-Kabri. It was depopulated on May 21, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. The terror from the nearby massacre at al-Kabri caused its residents to flee. The village was subsequently destroyed. Its lands were taken over by the Israeli settlement of Kabri.

name: Tarshiha
story: Tarshiha was a large and prosperous Christian and Muslim village in the Upper Galilee. It was captured on October 29, 1948, during Operation Hiram after being heavily shelled. A massacre was reported in the village, with Israeli soldiers killing a number of civilians. The Muslim population was entirely expelled, while the Christian residents were concentrated into one neighborhood. The Israeli town of Ma'alot was established on its lands in 1957, and the two were later merged into the municipality of Ma'alot-Tarshiha, a forced co-existence that masks the ethnic cleansing of the Muslim population.

name: Umm al-Faraj
story: A small village near the coast, Umm al-Faraj was depopulated on May 21, 1948. It was captured by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Ben-Ami. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ben Ami, named after the military operation that destroyed the village, was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Az-Zeeb
story: An ancient coastal village on the site of the biblical city of Achzib, az-Zeeb was a fishing and agricultural community. It was captured on May 14, 1948, by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Ben-Ami. The villagers were expelled, most fleeing to Lebanon. The village was then largely destroyed, with the exception of its mosque and the house of the former mukhtar. The site was later turned into a national park, and the Israeli settlement of Gesher HaZiv was established on its lands.

name: al-Batani al-Gharbi
story: The 'western' of two villages named al-Batani, this community on the southern coastal plain depended on agriculture, cultivating grain and citrus. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on May 13, 1948, during Operation Barak. The operation's explicit goal was to ethnically cleanse the area to secure the rear of Zionist forces advancing on Jaffa. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Azrikam was established on its lands in 1950.

name: al-Batani al-Sharqi
story: The 'eastern' village of al-Batani, this community shared the fate of its western neighbor. It was also captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak on May 13, 1948. The offensive was designed to create a depopulated corridor, and the expulsion of the villagers of al-Batani al-Sharqi was a necessary part of this plan. After its residents were driven out, the village was completely demolished. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Ahim was established nearby, and its lands were taken over by the state.

name: Barbarah
story: A large coastal village north of Gaza city, Barbarah was known for its agriculture, particularly grapes, figs, and almonds. It was captured on November 4-5, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Yoav. The villagers had resisted earlier attacks but were finally forced to flee by the overwhelming force of the Israeli offensive. The village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Mavki'im and Talmei Yafeh were established on its lands.

name: Barqa
story: A village on the coastal plain, Barqa was depopulated on May 13, 1948. It was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak. The operation's orders were to 'cleanse' the area of its Palestinian inhabitants. The villagers of Barqa were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Gan Yavne was founded nearby and expanded onto the village's former lands.

name: Bayt 'Affa
story: Bayt 'Affa was a village on the southern coastal plain that became a battlefield. It was captured and recaptured multiple times by Israeli and Egyptian forces during the summer of 1948. It was finally taken by Israeli forces during Operation Yoav in October. By this time, the village had been completely destroyed in the fighting, and its inhabitants had fled or been expelled. The Israeli settlement of Yad Natan was established on its lands.

name: Bayt Daras
story: A large and fiercely independent village, Bayt Daras was renowned for its history of resistance. It was subjected to several major attacks. On May 11, 1948, the Givati Brigade launched a major assault, which was initially repulsed. The village was finally captured on May 21 after a brutal attack that included shelling and the use of aircraft. A massacre occurred after its fall, with soldiers shooting civilians as they tried to flee. The village was then completely destroyed to prevent any return. The Israeli settlements of Giv'ati and Azrikam were built on its lands.

name: Bayt Jirja
story: A village located north of Gaza city, Bayt Jirja was captured on November 4-5, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during the final stages of Operation Yoav. Its capture was part of the push to isolate Gaza city. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Zohar was later built on its lands, and a pipeline carrying water from the Nile to the Negev was run through the site.

name: Bayt Tima
story: A village on the coastal plain, Bayt Tima was captured on October 19, 1948, during Operation Yoav. The capture of the village by the Givati Brigade was part of the effort to cut off Egyptian forces. After its residents were expelled, the village was destroyed. Its lands are now used for agriculture by the Israeli settlement of Timorim.

name: Bil'in
story: A small village in the Gaza district, Bil'in was depopulated on July 8, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The Givati Brigade captured the village as it pushed to clear the area between Israeli-held territory and the Egyptian lines. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the agricultural holdings of the nearby Israeli settlement of Kfar Menahem.

name: Burayr
story: A large and important village on the main road to Gaza, Burayr was a major market center for the surrounding area. It was captured on May 13, 1948, by the Negev Brigade during Operation Barak. The capture was preceded by a mortar barrage designed to terrorize the inhabitants into fleeing. Those who remained were expelled. The village was completely destroyed, and the Israeli settlements of Bror Hayil and Talmei Bilu were established on its lands.

name: Dayr Sunayd
story: A village located just north of the Gaza Strip, Dayr Sunayd had a station on the coastal railway line. It was captured on October 30, 1948, during Operation Yoav. The villagers had resisted earlier attacks but were ultimately overwhelmed. After the expulsion of its residents, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Erez was established on its lands, which later became a major Israeli checkpoint controlling movement in and out of the Gaza Strip.

name: Dimra
story: A village northeast of Gaza city, Dimra was known for its mosque and the shrine of a local holy man. It was captured late in the war, on October 28, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Yoav. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Erez was established on its lands.

name: al-Faluja
story: A large village that became the site of the 'Faluja pocket,' where 4,000 Egyptian troops, including a young officer named Gamal Abdel Nasser, were besieged by Israeli forces for several months. The 1949 Armistice Agreement signed between Israel and Egypt explicitly stipulated that the 3,140 Palestinian civilians in al-Faluja and the neighboring village of Iraq al-Manshiyya would be allowed to remain safely in their homes under Israeli rule. However, Israeli forces immediately violated this provision. Over several weeks, they engaged in a campaign of terror and intimidation—including beatings, threats, and nighttime raids—to force all inhabitants to leave. By April 1949, the entire civilian population had been expelled to Hebron and Gaza. The village was then completely destroyed and the city of Kiryat Gat was built on its lands.
israeli_settlement: Kiryat Gat, Plugot Forest, Shahar, Noga, Nir Hen, Nehora

name: Hamama
story: A very large coastal town and a center for weaving, Hamama was located just north of al-Majdal (Ashkelon). It was captured on November 4, 1948, during Operation Yoav. Like the residents of al-Majdal, its large population was not immediately expelled but was concentrated and contained. Over the following year, through a campaign of intimidation and coercion, the residents were forced to leave for the Gaza Strip. The town was then destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Nitzanim and Beit Ezra were established on its lands.

name: Hatta
story: A village on the coastal plain, Hatta was captured and depopulated on July 17-18, 1948, during the 'Death to the Invader' operation, which was an extension of Operation An-Far. The Givati Brigade captured the village, expelled its inhabitants, and later destroyed it. The Israeli settlements of Revaha and Zavdiel were established on its lands.

name: Hiribya
story: A large coastal village, Hiribya was captured in the early days of Operation Yoav in October 1948. The villagers had resisted earlier attacks. After its capture by the Givati Brigade, the inhabitants were expelled. The village was destroyed, and the Israeli settlements of Zikim and Karmia were established on its lands. The site of the former village is now a tourist beach.

name: Huj
story: The village of Huj was built on land that the residents had leased from the neighboring Jewish settlement of Dorot, with which they had friendly relations. Despite these relations, on May 31, 1948, the Negev Brigade expelled the villagers. They were not allowed to take their possessions and were forced into the Gaza Strip. The commander of Dorot protested the expulsion, but to no avail. The village was destroyed, and the Israeli settlement of Dorot expanded onto its lands.

name: Hulayqat
story: Hulayqat was a village located near a strategic British police fort and an oil field, making it a key military objective. It was the site of fierce fighting and changed hands several times. It was finally captured by the Givati Brigade on October 19, 1948, during Operation Yoav. The capture of Hulayqat was a turning point in the southern front. Its residents fled or were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli moshav of Heletz was later established on its lands, its name a Hebraicized version of the village's name.

name: 'Ibdis
story: 'Ibdis was a village on the southern coastal plain that was captured on July 8-9, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The Givati Brigade's offensive aimed to stop the Egyptian advance, and the capture of villages like 'Ibdis was part of this strategy. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Gei'a was established on its lands.

name: Iraq al-Manshiyya
story: A large village located next to al-Faluja, Iraq al-Manshiyya was besieged along with it in the 'Faluja pocket.' The 1949 Armistice Agreement explicitly guaranteed the right of its civilian population to remain. This agreement was violated by the Israeli army. Along with the residents of al-Faluja, the villagers were subjected to a campaign of intimidation and terror until they were all forcibly expelled by April 1949. The village was then completely destroyed, and the city of Kiryat Gat was built on its ruins.

name: Iraq Suwaydan
story: The strategic importance of Iraq Suwaydan was defined entirely by a fortified British police station (a Tegart fort) that dominated the village and the surrounding landscape. This fort became a key stronghold for the Egyptian army. Israeli forces launched eight separate and costly attempts to capture it between May and November 1948, all of which were repulsed, turning the fort into a symbol of humiliating failure for the IDF. It finally fell on November 9, 1948, during Operation Yoav, after a massive, coordinated assault involving heavy artillery and aerial bombardment. The village was destroyed, and the settlements of Yad Natan and Otzem were established on its lands.

name: Isdud
story: An large, ancient village on the site of the biblical Philistine city of Ashdod. It became a key frontline position occupied by the Egyptian army and was subjected to heavy aerial and naval bombardment during Operation Yoav. On October 28, 1948, the Egyptian army withdrew, and the bulk of the civilian population fled with them. The 300 villagers who remained were immediately expelled southwards by Israeli forces. The modern Israeli city of Ashdod was built nearby, and the settlements of Sde Uziyahu and Shtulim were established on its lands.
israeli_settlement: Ashdod, Sde Uziyahu, Shtulim, Bene Darom, Gan HaDarom

name: al-Jaladiyya
story: A small village on the coastal plain, al-Jaladiyya was depopulated on July 8, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The Givati Brigade's offensive cleared a path between Majdal and the western Hebron hills. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Orot was later established on its lands.

name: Julis
story: A village located near a strategic road junction and a former British military camp, Julis was captured on June 11, 1948, by the Givati Brigade at the beginning of the first truce. The villagers had repelled an earlier attack in May. After its capture, the villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Hodaya was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Jiyya
story: A village north of Gaza city, al-Jiyya was depopulated on November 4-5, 1948, during Operation Yoav. It was captured by the Givati Brigade as Israeli forces pushed south towards Gaza. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Gei'a was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Jura
story: A village on the coastal plain just south of al-Majdal, al-Jura's economy was based on agriculture and fishing. It was captured on November 4-5, 1948, during Operation Yoav. Like the inhabitants of al-Majdal and Hamama, its residents were not immediately expelled but were concentrated into the Majdal ghetto. Over the next year, they were subjected to a campaign of coercion by the Israeli military, which ultimately forced their expulsion to the Gaza Strip in 1950. The village was then completely destroyed, and the Israeli city of Ashkelon expanded to cover its lands.

name: Julis
story: A village located near a strategic road junction and a former British military camp, Julis was captured on June 11, 1948, by the Givati Brigade at the beginning of the first truce. The villagers had repelled an earlier attack in May. After its capture, the villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Hodaya was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Jiyya
story: A village north of Gaza city, al-Jiyya was depopulated on November 4-5, 1948, during Operation Yoav. It was captured by the Givati Brigade as Israeli forces pushed south towards Gaza. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Gei'a was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Kawkaba
story: A village on the southern coastal plain, Kawkaba was captured by the Givati Brigade on May 14, 1948, during Operation Barak. The operation was designed to clear the area of its Palestinian population. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli moshav of Kokhav Michael was established on its lands in 1950, its name a Hebraicized version of the village's name.

name: al-Khisas
story: A village in the northern Hula Valley, al-Khisas was the site of a massacre that served as a catalyst for the clearing of the region. On the night of December 18, 1947, Palmach commandos raided the village and blew up houses, killing at least 10 civilians, including women and children. The attack was a 'retaliation' but was deliberately targeted at a peaceful village to spread terror. The remaining inhabitants fled in the subsequent months, and the village was finally occupied and destroyed during Operation Yiftach in May 1948. The Israeli settlement of HaGoshrim was built on its lands.

name: al-Masmiyya al-Kabira
story: Al-Masmiyya al-Kabira ('the large Masmiyya') was a major village at a critical road junction on the southern coastal plain. It had a vibrant community with a mosque, two elementary schools, and a thriving market. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on July 9-11, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The offensive was part of the effort to clear the flanks of the main Israeli thrust southwards. All of its inhabitants were expelled upon its capture, and the village was later completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Bnei Re'em, Hatzav, and Yinnon were built on its land.

name: al-Masmiyya al-Saghira
story: The 'small' Masmiyya was a village located near its larger namesake. It was depopulated during the same offensive, Operation An-Far, on July 9, 1948. The Givati Brigade's sweep through the area aimed to create a depopulated zone, and the residents of al-Masmiyya al-Saghira were expelled along with their neighbors. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar HaRif was established on its lands in 1956.

name: al-Muharraqa
story: A village in the northern Negev, al-Muharraqa was captured by the Yiftach Brigade on May 28, 1948. The capture was part of an operation to secure the southern front. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Tlamim was established on its lands in 1950.

name: Najd
story: A small village located northeast of Gaza City, Najd was depopulated on May 13, 1948. It was captured by the Negev Brigade during Operation Barak. The operation's goal was to clear the area around Jewish settlements. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli town of Sderot was established on its lands in 1951.

name: Ni'ilya
story: A village just north of al-Majdal, Ni'ilya was captured on November 4-5, 1948, during Operation Yoav. After its capture by the Givati Brigade, its residents were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Talmei Yafeh was established on its lands.

name: Qastina
story: A village on the southern coastal plain, Qastina was captured on July 9, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. The village was strategically located on a major road. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Arugot and Kfar Ahim were established on its lands, and the large military base and airfield of Hatzor were also built on the village's territory.

name: Sawafir al-Gharbiyya
story: The 'western' of three villages named Sawafir, this community was captured by the Givati Brigade on May 18, 1948. The villagers had repulsed a previous attack, but were eventually overwhelmed. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Merkaz Shapira was established on its lands in 1948.

name: Sawafir al-Shamaliyya
story: The 'northern' Sawafir village was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Barak. The capture of the three Sawafir villages was a key objective for the Givati Brigade to secure control over the Majdal-Latrun road. After its residents were expelled, the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Merkaz Shapira.

name: Sawafir al-Sharqiyya
story: The 'eastern' Sawafir village was captured on May 12, 1948, during Operation Barak. The Givati Brigade's offensive systematically cleared the area. A massacre was reported to have occurred in the village, with soldiers killing a number of surrendering men. After the expulsion of the villagers, the community was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ein Tzurim was established on its lands.

name: Summayl
story: A village built on a hilltop on the southern coastal plain, Summayl was captured on July 8-9, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. The capture of the village was part of an effort to expand the Israeli-controlled corridor to the Negev. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Karmiya, Sgula, and Nachala were later established on its lands.

name: Tall al-Turmus
story: A small village on the coastal plain, Tall al-Turmus was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948. It was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Timorim was established on its lands.

name: Yasur
story: Yasur was a village on the coastal plain that had repelled several attacks before it was finally captured on June 11, 1948, by the Givati Brigade. The capture occurred at the start of the first truce. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Talmei Yehiel was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Jalil, Khirbat
story: A small village in the Lower Galilee, Khirbat al-Jalil was depopulated in May 1948. Its fate was linked to the fall of the larger nearby towns and the general sweep of Israeli forces through the area. The villagers fled or were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The lands were later taken over by the Israeli city of Migdal HaEmek.

name: Indur
story: Located on the site of the biblical town of Endor, this village was captured on May 24, 1948, by the Golani Brigade. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ein Dor was established nearby in 1948, appropriating the ancient name while erasing the modern Palestinian village.

name: Ma'lul
story: A predominantly Christian village west of Nazareth, Ma'lul had a history dating back to at least the Roman era. Its residents were known for their close social and economic ties with Nazareth. The village was occupied on July 15, 1948, during Operation Dekel, just one day before the capture of Nazareth itself. Its inhabitants were expelled, with many taking refuge in Nazareth and Yafa, where they and their descendants live today as 'present absentees'—internally displaced citizens denied the right to return to their homes. The village was completely leveled, with the exception of its two churches (one Greek Catholic, one Roman Catholic) and its mosque, which stand today as stark, lonely witnesses in a pine forest planted over the ruins by the Jewish National Fund (JNF).

name: al-Mujaydil
story: A large mixed Muslim and Christian village strategically located on the Nazareth-Haifa highway, al-Mujaydil was a bustling commercial center. It was occupied by the Golani Brigade on July 14-15, 1948, during Operation Dekel. The attack on the village served as a strategic diversion for the main Israeli assault on the city of Nazareth. Following its capture, al-Mujaydil was completely emptied of its inhabitants, who were forced to flee. The village was subsequently razed to the ground to make way for the establishment and expansion of the Israeli development town of Migdal HaEmek, an act of demographic transformation central to the colonization of Galilee.

name: Saffuriyya
story: The largest and most prominent village in the Nazareth sub-district, Saffuriyya was built on a strategic hill over the ruins of the ancient Roman-Jewish capital of Galilee, Sepphoris. It was occupied on the night of July 15-16, 1948, during Operation Dekel. According to Israeli military archives, the village 'put up strong resistance,' which led to an order for a heavy aerial bombardment with 'barrel bombs.' The bombing caused numerous casualties and widespread panic, prompting the flight of many residents. The remaining villagers were forcibly expelled. A small number who managed to return were rounded up and expelled again in January 1949. The Israeli settlement of Tzippori now stands on the site.
israeli_settlement: Tzippori, HaSolelim, Allon HaGalil, Hoshaya, Hanton

name: al-Haditha
story: Al-Haditha was a village with ancient origins, mentioned by the Roman historian Josephus. It was located near the city of Lydda. The village was captured on July 12, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade as part of Operation Dani. Its capture occurred in conjunction with the infamous assault on Lydda and Ramla, which involved a large-scale massacre and the forced expulsion of some 70,000 civilians. The inhabitants of al-Haditha were also expelled. The Israeli settlement of Hadid was established on its ruins in 1949.

name: al-Na'ani
story: A village situated on the coastal plain, al-Na'ani's residents were primarily engaged in agriculture, cultivating grain, sesame, and fruit, particularly citrus. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade on May 14, 1948, during Operation Barak. The operation's explicit goal was to ethnically cleanse the area. Following its capture and the expulsion of its residents, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Ramot Meir and Ganne Hadar were later established on its lands.

name: Salbit
story: A village in the Latrun salient, Salbit was captured by Israeli forces on July 15-16, 1948, during Operation Dani. However, it was retaken by the Jordanian Arab Legion. The village ended up in the no-man's land established by the 1949 Armistice Agreement. Despite this, Israel occupied the village site in the early 1950s, destroyed it, and established Kibbutz Sha'alvim on its lands in 1951, in violation of the armistice.

name: al-Tina
story: Al-Tina was a village on the southern coastal plain whose residents were farmers. It was depopulated on July 8-9, 1948, at the very beginning of the 'Ten Days' offensive between the first and second truces. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. Its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Ahim was established on its land in 1949.

name: 'Innaba
story: A village located on the western edge of the Latrun salient, 'Innaba was captured on July 10, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during the initial phase of Operation Dani. The capture of 'Innaba was part of the pincer movement to surround and depopulate the major cities of Lydda and Ramla. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Shmu'el was established on its lands in 1950.

name: Jilya
story: A village on the southern coastal plain, Jilya was depopulated on July 9, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade as it pushed to create a wedge between Egyptian and Jordanian forces. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Giv'at Brenner, established earlier, expanded its farmlands over the village's former territory.

name: Kharruba
story: A small village in the Ramle sub-district, Kharruba was depopulated on July 10, 1948. It was captured by the Givati Brigade during the broad sweep of Operation Dani. Like many smaller communities in the path of a major offensive, its inhabitants fled or were expelled by the advancing forces. The village was then destroyed. The site is now forested, and its lands are used by nearby settlements.

name: Majdal Yaba
story: An ancient village with a history stretching back to the Roman era, Majdal Yaba (also known as Majdal al-Sadiq) was built around a Mamluk-era fortress. It was captured on July 12, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Dani. The villagers were expelled, and most of the village was destroyed, though the fortress remains. The Israeli settlement of Rosh HaAyin was established on its lands.

name: al-Mukhayzin
story: Al-Mukhayzin was a village located on the coastal plain. It was depopulated on April 6, 1948, during Operation Nachshon. The village was attacked by the Givati Brigade as part of the effort to clear the area around the main road to Jerusalem. Its residents were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Beit Hilkia was established on its lands in 1953.

name: Sarafand al-'Amar
story: Sarafand al-'Amar was a village located next to the massive British military base of Sarafand. On April 15, 1948, a village leader was summoned by the Haganah to a meeting and assassinated. This act of terror caused many of the villagers to flee. The village was finally occupied on May 15 and completely destroyed. The Israeli military base, renamed Tzrifin, was expanded over the village site, and the settlement of Nir Tzvi was also built on its lands.

name: Sarafand al-Kharab
story: The 'ruined' Sarafand, this village was located on the coastal plain. It was depopulated on May 20, 1948. Haganah forces attacked the village, forcing its inhabitants to flee. The village was then completely destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Nes Ziona and Rishon LeZion expanded to cover its lands.

name: al-Tira
story: Not to be confused with the larger village of the same name in the Haifa district, this al-Tira was located south of Lydda. It was depopulated on July 10, 1948, during Operation Dani. The village was captured by the Alexandroni Brigade, and its inhabitants were expelled. The Israeli settlement of Tirat Yehuda was established on its lands, appropriating its name.

name: Taytaba
story: A small village in the Upper Galilee, Taytaba was captured on October 30, 1948, during Operation Hiram. Its capture by the Sheva' (7th) Brigade coincided with the massacres at Safsaf and Saliha, which created a wave of terror across the region, forcing many to flee. The residents of Taytaba were expelled, and their village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Dalton was established nearby and took over its lands.

name: al-Talawiyya
story: A small village in the Hula Valley, al-Talawiyya was depopulated on May 25, 1948. It was captured by the Palmach during the final sweep of Operation Yiftach. The villagers were forced to flee, most likely into Syria, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Lehavot HaBashan was later established on its lands.

name: al-'Ulmaniyya
story: A small village east of the Jordan River, al-'Ulmaniyya was inhabited by the 'Arab al-Sayyad tribe. It was depopulated on April 20, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. Its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Yesud HaMa'ala, founded earlier, expanded its lands to cover the site.

name: al-Wayziyya
story: A village in the Hula Valley, al-Wayziyya was depopulated on May 25, 1948, during the final stages of Operation Yiftach. The Palmach offensive systematically cleared the valley of all its Palestinian inhabitants. The villagers of al-Wayziyya were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Yesud HaMa'ala later took over its lands.

name: Yarda
story: A small village on the western edge of the Hula Valley, Yarda was depopulated on October 31, 1948, during Operation Hiram. After its capture by Israeli forces, its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ayelet HaShahar, established nearby, expanded its agricultural lands over the site.

name: al-Zahiriyya al-Tahta
story: The 'lower' of two villages named al-Zahiriyya, this community was located north of Safad. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The fall of Safad created a wave of terror that led the inhabitants of surrounding villages to flee. After the village was emptied, it was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Rosh Pinna expanded to cover its lands.

name: al-Zawiya
story: A small village in the Hula Valley, al-Zawiya was depopulated on May 24, 1948. It was captured by the Palmach during Operation Yiftach as part of the systematic clearing of the valley. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was demolished. The Israeli settlement of Neot Mordechai was later established on its lands.

name: al-Zuhayriyya
story: Al-Zuhayriyya was a small village in the northern Hula Valley, inhabited by the 'Arab al-Sayyad tribe. It was depopulated on May 22, 1948, during Operation Yiftach. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed as part of the ethnic cleansing of the region. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Amir.

name: al-Zanqariyya
story: A village inhabited by the 'Arab al-Zanqariyya Bedouin tribe, it was located north of the Sea of Galilee. It was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh ('Broom'), a precursor to Yiftach. The operation aimed to clear the Bedouin tribes from the area. The residents were forcibly expelled from their homes, and their encampment was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Elifelet was established on its lands.

name: al-Zahiriyya
story: A large town south of Hebron, al-Zahiriyya was not depopulated during the 1948 war and remained under Jordanian control. However, it was captured by the Israeli army in the 1967 war and has been under military occupation ever since. It has suffered from extensive land confiscation for the construction of the Apartheid Wall and illegal Israeli settlements, such as Tene and Shima. Its story is one of ongoing colonization and resistance under occupation, rather than Nakba-era expulsion.

name: Kafr 'Imrin
story: A small village in the Jenin sub-district, Kafr 'Imrin was depopulated during the war in 1948. Its proximity to the main battle lines and the general advance of Israeli forces led to its evacuation. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later absorbed by the state of Israel.

name: Mafjar al-Khayr
story: A small locality on the coast, Mafjar al-Khayr was depopulated in March 1948. It was part of the area cleared by the Haganah in its systematic campaign to create a contiguous Zionist-controlled coastal strip. The residents were forced out, and the area was later developed as part of the industrial and recreational zone of the Israeli city of Hadera.

name: Khirbat al-Manara
story: A small village in the coastal plain area of the Haifa sub-district, Khirbat al-Manara was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by Zionist forces during the operations to secure the coast and the main roads. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ma'anit was established nearby and took over its lands.

name: Khirbat al-Shuna
story: A small village in the Haifa sub-district, Khirbat al-Shuna was depopulated in May 1948. Its capture was part of the general sweep by Haganah forces to clear the hinterland after the fall of Haifa. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The lands were later absorbed by the state.

name: Naghnaghiyya
story: A village located on the plain east of Haifa, Naghnaghiyya was depopulated on April 22, 1948. Its fate was sealed by the fall of Haifa and the subsequent operations to clear the surrounding area. The villagers were forced to flee, and their homes were destroyed. The expanding suburbs of Haifa and Kiryat Ata now cover the site.

name: Wadi al-Qarn
story: A small Bedouin settlement in the Western Galilee, Wadi al-Qarn was depopulated on May 14, 1948. It was captured by the Carmeli Brigade during Operation Ben-Ami. The offensive systematically cleared the region's Palestinian communities. The residents were expelled, and their encampment was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Goren was established nearby.

name: al-Kafrayn
story: A village located in the hills southeast of Haifa, al-Kafrayn was captured on April 12, 1948, during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. Haganah forces operating out of the Jewish settlement attacked and occupied the village as part of a counter-offensive designed to clear the surrounding area. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ein HaEmek was established on its lands in 1944 and later expanded.

name: Khubbayza
story: A small village in the Carmel foothills, Khubbayza was depopulated on May 12, 1948. It was captured by the Alexandroni Brigade during its operations to clear the coastal plain hinterland. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The site of the former village is now covered by a forest, a common JNF tactic to erase Palestinian presence.

name: Lidd
story: Not to be confused with the major city of Lydda, this village, also known as Khirbat Lidd, was located in the Jezreel Valley. It was captured on April 30, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during the operations that followed the battle for Mishmar HaEmek. Its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Givat Oz.

name: Qisarya
story: A small fishing village built amidst the magnificent ruins of the ancient Roman city of Caesarea Maritima. It was depopulated on February 15, 1948, in a very early act of ethnic cleansing. The Haganah, under the pretext of security, began demolishing the villagers' houses, forcing them to flee. After the expulsion, the remaining homes were destroyed. The site was later developed into a major Israeli national park and an affluent luxury town, Caesarea, which capitalizes on the ancient Roman ruins while completely erasing the history of the Palestinian community that had lived there for centuries.

name: Bayt Jiz
story: A village on the coastal plain, Bayt Jiz was captured on May 15, 1948, during Operation Makkabi. The operation was designed to clear the corridor to Jerusalem. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Harel, named after the Haganah brigade that fought in the area, was established on its lands in 1948.

name: Khirbat al-Buwayra
story: A small village in the Latrun salient, Khirbat al-Buwayra was depopulated on May 18, 1948. It was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation Makkabi. The villagers were forced to flee, and the village was destroyed. The site is now covered by the JNF-planted 'Canada Park', an area designed to conceal the ruins of several destroyed Palestinian villages.

name: al-Khunayfisa
story: A small village in the Jezreel Valley, al-Khunayfisa was depopulated on April 12, 1948. It was captured by Haganah forces during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later absorbed by the Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaEmek.

name: Latrun
story: Latrun was not a village but a strategic complex consisting of a Trappist monastery, a Tegart police fort, and a pumping station. The police fort was a major obstacle on the road to Jerusalem and the site of several bloody, failed Israeli attacks against the Jordanian Arab Legion during the war. While the monastery survived, the surrounding Palestinian communities were destroyed. The police fort is now an Israeli military museum, and the area is covered by 'Canada Park', built over the ruins of the depopulated villages of 'Amwas, Yalu, and Bayt Nuba, which were destroyed after the 1967 war, not in 1948.

name: al-Maghar
story: Al-Maghar was a large village known for its distinctive houses built into a hillside, giving it its name ('The Caves'). The village had a diverse population and a rich history. It was captured on May 15, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak. According to historical accounts, a massacre occurred in the village after its occupation. Soldiers reportedly separated men from the women and children and executed dozens of them. The rest of the population was expelled. The village was later destroyed, and the settlement of Beit Elazari was founded on its lands.

name: al-Na'ima
story: Not to be confused with the village of the same name in Safad, this al-Na'ima was on the coastal plain. It was depopulated on May 14, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak. The villagers were forced to flee under attack, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Yad Binyamin was established on its lands.

name: 'Amwas
story: An ancient village of great historical and religious significance, identified with the biblical Emmaus. 'Amwas was not depopulated in 1948 but was occupied and completely destroyed by the Israeli army immediately following the 1967 war. On June 7, 1967, Israeli soldiers expelled the entire population of 'Amwas, along with the neighboring villages of Yalu and Bayt Nuba, at gunpoint. The villages were then systematically bulldozed to the ground. The expulsions and destruction were a deliberate war crime aimed at clearing the Latrun salient. Canada Park was later built over the ruins, funded by Canadian donors, to conceal the crime.

name: Yibna
story: An ancient and major Palestinian town with a history stretching back to the Philistines, Yibna was a bustling commercial and agricultural hub. It was captured on June 4, 1948, by the Givati Brigade after being shelled by mortars. The attack caused widespread panic, and the vast majority of its 6,000 residents fled. The few who remained were expelled. The town was then occupied by Zionist forces and later settled by Jewish immigrants, becoming the Israeli city of Yavne.

name: Abu Tulul
story: A Bedouin locality in the Negev desert, Abu Tulul was depopulated in 1949. After the war, the Israeli military government began a systematic campaign to concentrate the Bedouin population into a restricted zone. The residents of Abu Tulul were forcibly removed from their lands, which were then taken over by the state for military use or new settlements. The Israeli settlement of Neve Midbar was later built on the site.

name: al-'Araqib
story: Al-'Araqib is a Bedouin village in the Negev that has become a powerful symbol of steadfastness. The tribe was expelled from their lands in 1951 by the Israeli military. Despite this, they have waged a decades-long struggle to return. Since 2010, the village has been demolished by Israeli forces over 200 times, yet each time, the residents return and rebuild. Their struggle highlights the ongoing Nakba against the Bedouin population of the Negev, who are continuously displaced for the expansion of JNF forests and new Jewish towns.

name: Asluj
story: A Bedouin center in the Negev, Asluj was located at a strategic crossroads. It was captured by the Negev Brigade on December 26, 1948, during Operation Horev. The residents were expelled, and the settlement was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mash'abei Sade was established on its lands.

name: al-Atawina
story: A large Bedouin tribe whose lands were in the northern Negev, the al-Atawina were forcibly displaced in 1948-49. During and after the war, Israeli forces systematically cleared the Negev of its Bedouin population, forcing them into a restricted zone or out of the country altogether. The lands of the al-Atawina were expropriated by the state and are now used by several Israeli settlements.

name: al-Baha
story: A small settlement near the coast, al-Baha was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by the Negev Brigade during Operation Barak. The offensive cleared the area, forcing the residents to flee. The settlement was destroyed, and its lands were incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Netiv HaAsara.

name: al-Chalazat
story: A Bedouin center on the site of the ancient Nabatean city of Elusa, al-Chalazat (al-Khalasa) was a key location in the Negev desert. The village was captured during Operation Yoav in October 1948. Following the Israeli army's occupation of the area, the inhabitants were forcibly expelled, part of the systematic removal of the Bedouin population from the northern Negev. The village was destroyed, and its extensive archaeological ruins were later designated as an Israeli national park, privileging ancient history over the modern community that was erased.

name: al-Haram (Sayyidna 'Ali)
story: Also known as Sayyidna 'Ali, al-Haram was a coastal village north of Tel Aviv, revered for housing the magnificent shrine of a Muslim saint, 'Ali ibn 'Alim. The village was depopulated in early February 1948 as part of the Haganah's systematic clearing of the coastal plain. Its inhabitants were forced to flee under threat of attack. The beautiful shrine was left standing but has been repeatedly vandalized. The Israeli city of Herzliya, established earlier, expanded its Pitu'ah district onto the village lands, and the ruins of the village now lie next to a beach and tourist area.

name: Ijlil al-Qibliyya
story: The 'southern' of two adjacent villages named Ijlil, this community was located just north of al-Haram. It was depopulated on April 3, 1948, as part of the same coastal clearing operation conducted by the Alexandroni Brigade. The operation aimed to create a contiguous Jewish-controlled territory along the coast, which required the removal of the Palestinian population. After the villagers were expelled, their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Glil Yam was established on its lands in 1943 and later expanded.

name: Ijlil al-Shamaliyya
story: The 'northern' village of Ijlil, this community was depopulated along with its southern neighbor on April 3, 1948. The Alexandroni Brigade's offensive along the coast was systematic and swift, forcing the inhabitants to abandon their homes and lands under military pressure. The destruction of the Ijlil villages was part of a clear strategic plan to remove the Palestinian presence from the valuable coastal strip north of Tel Aviv. The lands of the village were later absorbed by the Israeli city of Herzliya.

name: al-Jammasin al-Gharbi
story: This was one of two villages inhabited by the Jammasin clan, who were traditionally known for raising water buffaloes. It was located on the north side of the al-'Awja (Yarkon) River. The village was depopulated in March 1948. Haganah forces surrounded the village and, through a campaign of intimidation and the firing of 'a few shots,' coerced the inhabitants into fleeing. The village was then incorporated into the rapidly expanding city of Tel Aviv, and its residents became refugees.

name: al-Jammasin al-Sharqi
story: The 'eastern' village of the Jammasin clan, this community shared the same fate as its western counterpart. It was depopulated in March 1948 as part of the Haganah's effort to clear the immediate hinterland of Tel Aviv. The pressure and intimidation from Zionist forces forced the villagers to abandon their homes and traditional way of life. The village was subsequently demolished and completely absorbed into the urban fabric of Tel Aviv, its history erased by urban development.

name: al-Jiyada
story: A small locality in the Haifa sub-district, al-Jiyada was depopulated in May 1948. It was one of many small agricultural communities cleared by Haganah forces in the wake of the fall of Haifa, as they consolidated control over the hinterland. The residents were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The lands were later absorbed by the state.

name: Kafrayn
story: A village located in the hills southeast of Haifa, Kafrayn was captured on April 12, 1948, during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. Haganah forces operating out of the Jewish settlement attacked and occupied the village as part of a counter-offensive designed to clear the surrounding area. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ein HaEmek was established on its lands in 1944 and later expanded.

name: Dalayat al-Rawha'
story: A village in the hills southeast of Haifa, Dalayat al-Rawha' was depopulated in April 1948. It was one of the cluster of villages cleared by Haganah forces during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The villagers were forced to flee, and their homes were subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Dalia was established on its lands in 1939 and later expanded.

name: al-Dumayri
story: A small village in the coastal plain area of the Haifa sub-district, al-Dumayri was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by Haganah forces during the operations to secure the coast south of Haifa. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Zikhron Ya'akov, one of the oldest Zionist colonies, expanded its agricultural lands over the former village site.

name: Ghubayat al-Tahta
story: The 'lower' of two villages named Ghubayat, this community was depopulated in April 1948 during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. It was one of several villages in the Jezreel Valley cleared by Haganah forces to create a secure zone. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaEmek.

name: Ghubayat al-Fawqa
story: The 'upper' village of Ghubayat shared the fate of its lower neighbor. It was also captured and depopulated in April 1948 by Haganah forces during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The systematic clearing of these villages was a key part of the Zionist strategy to control the strategic Jezreel Valley. The village was destroyed, and its lands were taken over by Mishmar HaEmek.

name: al-Mazar (Haifa)
story: A small village on Mount Carmel, al-Mazar was built around the shrine of a revered holy man. The village was depopulated on July 16, 1948, during Operation Shoter. Although the nearby village of 'Ayn Hawd was re-established as an artist colony, al-Mazar was completely destroyed, and its residents were expelled. The site is now a tourist spot within a nature reserve.

name: Qira wa Qamun
story: A small twin village in the Jezreel Valley, Qira wa Qamun was depopulated in April 1948 during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The villagers were forced to flee by the advancing Haganah forces. The villages were then destroyed. The Israeli city of Yokneam Illit was later built on its lands.

name: Zarnuqa
story: Zarnuqa was a large village on the coastal plain that had a history of resisting British and Zionist forces. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on May 27, 1948. Following its capture, its inhabitants were systematically expelled over the following days. The village was then destroyed. The Israeli settlements of Zarnuqa and Giv'at Brenner were built on its lands.

name: al-Burj
story: A small village in the Latrun salient, al-Burj was captured on July 15, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Like other villages in the area (Bayt Shanna, Bir Ma'in), its capture and destruction were part of the plan to ethnically cleanse the Latrun area and widen the corridor to Jerusalem. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The site of the former village is now covered by forest.

name: Dayr Muhaysin
story: A village in the Latrun area, Dayr Muhaysin was captured on April 6, 1948, during Operation Nachshon. It was one of the first villages to be depopulated in the operation to open the road to Jerusalem. Haganah forces attacked the village, forcing its inhabitants to flee. The village was then completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Beko'a was established on its lands.

name: Dayr Abu Salama
story: A small khirba or settlement in the Ramle sub-district, Dayr Abu Salama was depopulated in July 1948 during Operation Dani. It was one of many small communities swept away by the massive offensive. Its residents were expelled, and the settlement was destroyed. Its lands were later absorbed by the state.

name: Idhnabba
story: A village located in the rolling hills of the Shephelah, Idhnabba's livelihood depended on agriculture, particularly cereals and olive trees. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. Its capture by the Givati Brigade was part of the offensive aimed at blocking the advance of the Egyptian army. The villagers were expelled, and the village was destroyed. No Israeli settlements were built directly on its former site, but its lands were taken over by surrounding settlements.

name: Jindas
story: An ancient village with a history that included a famous Mamluk-era bridge, Jindas was located near the city of Lydda. It was depopulated on July 10, 1948, during the initial assault of Operation Dani. The villagers were expelled as part of the offensive that led to the ethnic cleansing of Lydda and Ramla. The village was destroyed, and the Israeli settlement of Ginaton was established on its lands.

name: Khirbat al-Duhayriyya
story: A small village in the Ramle district, Khirbat al-Duhayriyya was depopulated in July 1948 during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the sweep to clear the area east of Ramla. The residents were expelled, and their homes were demolished. Its lands were later incorporated into the agricultural holdings of nearby Israeli settlements.

name: al-Kunayyisa
story: Meaning 'The Little Church,' al-Kunayyisa was a village located on rolling terrain. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The Givati Brigade captured the village as it pushed to create a corridor to the Negev. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The site of the former village is now part of an Israeli military area.

name: al-Qazaza
story: A village situated on a low hill, Qazaza's economy revolved around agriculture. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. Captured by the Givati Brigade, its inhabitants were expelled as part of the broader military goal of clearing the southern coastal plain. The village was completely destroyed after the war. The site is now covered by an Israeli military base and forest.

name: Sajad
story: Sajad was a small village whose lands were primarily used for cereal cultivation. It was depopulated on July 9-10, 1948, during Operation An-Far. The village was captured by the Givati Brigade during its push to control the area and block Egyptian forces. The inhabitants were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Today, the site is overgrown with wild vegetation, and its lands are used by the Israeli settlement of Kfar Menahem.

name: Shahma
story: Shahma was a small agricultural village on the southern coastal plain. It was depopulated on May 9, 1948, relatively early in the war, during Operation Barak. The Givati Brigade's orders for the operation involved the expulsion of Palestinian communities to secure the area around future Israeli settlements. After its inhabitants were expelled, the village was destroyed. The settlement of Pedaya was established on its lands in 1951.

name: al-Shaykh Sulayman
story: A small locality in the Gaza district, likely a Bedouin settlement. It was depopulated in 1948 during the Israeli military operations that swept through the Negev and the southern coastal plain. Like many smaller Bedouin encampments, its specific date of depopulation is not well-documented, but it was part of the general ethnic cleansing of the region. The residents were expelled, and the site was erased.

name: Sumsum
story: A village on the coastal plain, Sumsum was captured on May 12-13, 1948, by the Negev Brigade during Operation Barak. The villagers initially resisted the attack but were forced to flee under heavy fire. The village was then occupied and later completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Bror Hayil was established nearby, and its lands were taken over by the state.

name: al-Tell al-Safi
story: An ancient and strategically important village built on a large mound, identified with the biblical Philistine city of Gath. Al-Tell al-Safi was captured on July 9-10, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation An-Far. The villagers, including a large number of refugees from other areas, were expelled. According to soldier's testimony, several women were raped and murdered by the occupying soldiers. The village was then completely destroyed, and the Israeli settlement of Kfar Menahem expanded onto its lands.

name: Khirbat Umm Burj
story: A village in the western Hebron hills, Khirbat Umm Burj was captured on October 28-29, 1948, during Operation Yoav. It was one of many villages depopulated as Israeli forces pushed into the Hebron region. The inhabitants were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Nehushe was established nearby in 1982.

name: Bayt 'Itab
story: Built on the remains of an ancient Crusader fortress, Bayt 'Itab was a village with a commanding view of the surrounding hills. It was a known stronghold for Palestinian fighters during the war. The village was captured on October 21, 1948, during Operation ha-Har by the Harel Brigade. After a battle, the remaining inhabitants were expelled. Following its capture, the village was systematically destroyed. Today, the site is covered by the Israeli settlements of Nes Harim and Bar Giora, as well as the JNF-planted American Independence Park, which serves to conceal the history of Palestinian habitation and resistance.
israeli_settlement: Nes Harim, Bar Giora, American Independence Park

name: Ayn Ghazal
story: Ayn Ghazal was part of the 'Little Triangle' of resilient villages south of Haifa that held out against Zionist forces for months after the fall of the city. The village, which had a history of resistance dating back to the 1936-39 Arab revolt, was finally captured on July 26, 1948, during Operation Shoter ('Operation Policeman'). This was a massive, coordinated assault involving intense artillery shelling and, significantly, aerial bombardment by B-17 bombers. After its capture, UN investigators documented evidence of atrocities, including the killing of civilians. All remaining inhabitants were expelled, and the village was then systematically destroyed by the IDF over several days, an act of retribution and erasure.

name: Ijzim
story: A large and ancient village in the 'Little Triangle' with Ayn Ghazal, Ijzim had a history dating back to the Roman period and was home to a mosque, a church, and a shrine for a local sage. It was a center of steadfast resistance, holding out for months against Israeli encroachment. It finally fell on July 26, 1948, during the overwhelming assault of Operation Shoter, which involved heavy artillery and air power. After the village's fall, its remaining population was rounded up and expelled, with most forced towards Jinin. In the following weeks, the IDF systematically demolished the village's houses, leaving only the fortress-like home of a notable family and the mosque. The settlement of Kerem Maharal was later established on its lands.

name: al-Tantura
story: An ancient coastal fishing village built on the ruins of the Canaanite city of Dor, al-Tantura had a vibrant economy based on fishing, agriculture, and trade. It was captured on the night of May 22-23, 1948, by the Haganah's Alexandroni Brigade during Operation Namal ('Operation Port'). Following its surrender, a large-scale massacre occurred. Survivor testimonies and research by Israeli scholars have revealed that dozens of unarmed men were systematically executed by the soldiers—lined up and shot on the beach and in the village cemetery. The remaining population was then expelled, with women and children sent to a nearby village and the surviving men taken as prisoners. A mass grave is believed to exist under what is now the parking lot for Dor Beach, a fact that remains a subject of intense denial and controversy in Israel.

name: Abu Kishk
story: Abu Kishk was a large village inhabited by the Abu Kishk Bedouin tribe, who had settled there and become successful citrus growers. The village was depopulated on March 30, 1948. Haganah forces surrounded the village and demanded the surrender of their weapons. Following the surrender, the villagers were expelled by force, and their homes were demolished. The expulsion of this large community was a key step in the ethnic cleansing of the area north of Jaffa. The Israeli settlements of Hod HaSharon and Ramat HaSharon were built on its lands.

name: al-'Amiriya
story: A small village in the Tulkarm sub-district, al-'Amiriya was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured by Zionist forces during the operations to secure the coastal plain. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Cherut was established nearby and took over its lands.

name: al-Harithiyya
story: A village in the Jezreel Valley, al-Harithiyya was depopulated in April 1948. It was one of the many villages cleared by the Haganah during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The villagers were forced to flee, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sha'ar HaAmakim, founded earlier, expanded its lands to cover the site.

name: al-Jalama
story: A small village in the Tulkarm sub-district, al-Jalama was depopulated on March 1, 1948. It was an early casualty of the Haganah's operations to clear the coastal plain. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Lahavot Haviva was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Khayma
story: A small village in the Haifa sub-district, al-Khayma was depopulated in April 1948. It was captured during the operations to secure the coastal area south of Haifa. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the agricultural holdings of nearby Israeli settlements.

name: Ramin
story: Ramin was a village in the Tulkarm sub-district located in the hills east of the coastal plain. Unlike most villages in the 1948 territories, Ramin was not depopulated during the war itself. It remained on the Jordanian side of the 1949 armistice line and is today a town within the jurisdiction of the Palestinian Authority. Its story is one of survival and continued existence under occupation, rather than Nakba-era expulsion.

name: al-Shuna
story: A village inhabited by the 'Arab al-Shuna tribe, it was located near the Jordan River in the Safad district. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The villagers were forced to flee, and their settlement was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ayelet HaShahar expanded its lands to cover the site.

name: al-Tira
story: Not to be confused with other villages of the same name, this al-Tira was located in the Baysan Valley. It was captured on May 15, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Gazit was established on its lands.

name: Yubla
story: A small village in the hills west of the Sea of Galilee, Yubla was depopulated on May 12, 1948. It was captured by the Golani Brigade during the operations that followed the fall of Tiberias. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Kfar Tavor.

name: al-Zaytuna
story: A Bedouin locality in the Negev desert, al-Zaytuna was depopulated in 1948-49. It was part of the area systematically cleared by the Israeli army after the war to remove the Bedouin population and concentrate them in a restricted zone. The residents were forcibly removed from their lands, which were then expropriated by the state.

name: Zita
story: A village in the western Hebron district, Zita was depopulated on July 17-18, 1948. It was captured by the Givati Brigade during Operation Death to the Invader. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were later destroyed. The site of the former village is now an agricultural area used by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: al-Zubayd
story: A Bedouin village of the 'Arab al-Zubayd tribe, located north of the Sea of Galilee. It was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh ('Broom'). The operation was a precursor to Yiftach and specifically targeted Bedouin communities for expulsion. The residents were forced to flee, and their encampment was destroyed. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Rosh Pinna.

name: al-Zaytuna (Safad)
story: A small village near Safad, named for its olive groves. This village was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The fall of the city of Safad caused the residents of smaller, surrounding villages to flee in panic. Al-Zaytuna was subsequently destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the expanding city of Safad.

name: Suhmata
story: A large Christian and Muslim village perched on a high mountain in the Upper Galilee, Suhmata was captured on October 30, 1948, during Operation Hiram. The village was shelled by Israeli artillery before being occupied. After its capture, the residents were terrorized and then expelled, forced to walk into Lebanon. The village was completely destroyed by dynamite in early November. The Israeli settlement of Tzuriel was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-'Arab al-Shamalina
story: A Bedouin village on the northeastern shore of the Sea of Galilee, inhabited by the 'Arab al-Shamalina tribe. It was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh. The Palmach offensive cleared the entire area of its Bedouin population, forcing them to flee into Syria. Their lands were later taken over by nearby Israeli settlements.

name: al-Dalhamiyya
story: A village located at the confluence of the Jordan and Yarmuk rivers, al-Dalhamiyya was depopulated on May 15, 1948. It was captured by the Golani Brigade as part of the operations to secure the Jordan Valley. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ashdot Ya'akov, founded nearby, expanded its lands to cover the site.

name: Khirbat al-Wa'ra al-Sawda'
story: Meaning 'the ruin of the black rugged land,' this was a Bedouin settlement of the 'Arab al-Mawasi tribe. It was located north of the Sea of Galilee. The settlement was depopulated on May 4, 1948, during Operation Matateh ('Broom'). The operation was designed to clear all the Bedouin communities from the area. The residents were forcibly expelled, and their encampment was destroyed. The lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Ami'ad.

name: al-Qudayriyya
story: A village inhabited by the 'Arab al-Qudayriyya Bedouin tribe, it was located northwest of the Sea of Galilee. It was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The villagers were forced to flee by the Palmach's advance. The village was then destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the state.

name: Samra
story: A village on the eastern shore of the Sea of Galilee, Samra was depopulated in March 1948. It was one of the first villages in the area to be cleared by Haganah forces. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of HaOn was established on its lands in 1949. The area was declared a demilitarized zone under the 1949 armistice, but Israel retained control and colonized the land.

name: Zir'in
story: Zir'in was a large and historically prominent village, located on the site of the biblical city of Jezreel. It had a school for boys, a mosque, and a number of historical artifacts. The village was captured on May 28, 1948, by the Golani Brigade after a battle with the Arab Liberation Army. According to Israeli military sources, the capture was followed by the systematic destruction of the village to create a 'clear field of fire.' The villagers were expelled, and Kibbutz Yizra'el was established on its lands in August 1948, with its name being a Hebraicized version of the village's ancient name.

name: Balad al-Shaykh
story: A large and important village at the foot of Mount Carmel, Balad al-Shaykh was the burial site of Izz ad-Din al-Qassam, the revered Syrian cleric and revolutionary leader. On the night of December 31, 1947, in retaliation for the killing of Jewish workers at the nearby oil refinery, Haganah forces carried out a bloody massacre in the village, attacking homes with gunfire and grenades and killing up to 60 civilians, including women and children. This attack caused a mass exodus. The village was finally occupied on April 25, 1948, and the remaining inhabitants were expelled. It was one of the few villages not completely demolished; its houses were resettled by Jewish immigrants and it was renamed Tel Hanan.

name: 'Arab al-Nufay'at
story: A Bedouin community on the coastal plain, 'Arab al-Nufay'at was depopulated on April 10, 1948. Haganah forces operating in the area forced the residents to leave their encampment as part of the broader strategy to clear the coast. Their homes were destroyed, and their traditional grazing lands were expropriated by the state.

name: Bika
story: A small village in the Tulkarm sub-district, Bika was depopulated in May 1948. It was one of the many small agricultural communities on the coastal plain that were cleared by Haganah forces to create a secure, contiguous Zionist territory. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Baka-Jatt was later established nearby.

name: Burayka
story: A small village on the coastal plain south of Haifa, Burayka was depopulated on May 5, 1948. It was captured by Haganah forces during the operations to clear the coastal road. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The lands of the former village were later taken over by the Israeli town of Binyamina.

name: al-Ghubayya al-Tahta
story: The 'lower' of two villages named al-Ghubayya, this community was depopulated in April 1948 during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. It was one of several villages in the Jezreel Valley cleared by Haganah forces to create a secure zone. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaEmek.

name: al-Ghubayya al-Fawqa
story: The 'upper' of two villages named al-Ghubayya, it was depopulated in April 1948 during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The battle was a major turning point in the fight for the Jezreel Valley, and the Haganah's strategy involved clearing all surrounding Palestinian villages to secure the area. The residents of al-Ghubayya al-Fawqa were forced to flee by the advancing forces, and their village was completely destroyed. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Mishmar HaEmek.

name: 'Ayn Hawd
story: A village on the western slopes of Mount Carmel, 'Ayn Hawd was captured on July 12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Shoter. The villagers were expelled, but in a unique case, some of the residents refused to become refugees and instead established a new, unrecognized village nearby named Ein Hawd. The original village was not destroyed but was converted into an exclusive Jewish artists' colony in 1953 and renamed 'Ein Hod.' The story of 'Ayn Hawd is a stark example of cultural appropriation and the simultaneous steadfastness (sumud) of a community that refused to disappear.

name: al-Tira
story: Known as 'Tira of the almonds' (Tirat al-Lawz), this was one of the largest and most important villages in the Haifa sub-district, with a history dating to the Roman era. It was a major producer of olives and oil. Al-Tira faced a series of attacks beginning in December 1947, including a deadly Irgun bombing of a coffeehouse. The village finally fell on July 16, 1948, during the fierce 'Ten Days' battles. The assault was notable for being the first coordinated land-sea attack by Israeli forces; a warship bombarded the village from the Mediterranean before ground units from the Golani, Carmeli, and Alexandroni brigades moved in. The remaining villagers were expelled, and the village was almost entirely demolished, with the new Israeli town of Tirat Carmel built over its ruins.
destroyed_by: Irgun (IZL), Haganah (Golani, Carmeli, Alexandroni Brigades), Israeli Navy
israeli_settlement: Tirat Carmel, Kfar Galim, HaHotrim, Megadim, Beit Tzvi

name: Jaba'
story: A village on the coastal plain south of Haifa, Jaba' was part of the 'Little Triangle' of villages that resisted capture for months. It was finally captured on July 24-26, 1948, by the Carmeli and Alexandroni brigades during Operation Shoter. The massive offensive used artillery and air power to subdue the resilient villages. The inhabitants of Jaba' were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Geva Carmel was established on its lands in 1949.

name: Khirbat al-Sarkas
story: A small village inhabited by people of Circassian descent, Khirbat al-Sarkas was located on the coastal plain. It was depopulated on April 15, 1948. The village was cleared by Haganah forces as part of their operations to secure the coastal road and remove Palestinian communities from the area. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Binyamina, founded earlier, expanded its lands to cover the site.

name: Khirbat al-Sawamir
story: A small locality in the Haifa sub-district, Khirbat al-Sawamir was depopulated in May 1948 during the operations that secured the area south of Haifa. The residents were forced to flee by the advancing Haganah forces, and their homes were subsequently destroyed. Its lands were later absorbed by the state and nearby settlements.

name: Khirbat Lid
story: Also known as Lidd, this village was located in the Jezreel Valley. It was captured on April 30, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during the operations that followed the battle for Mishmar HaEmek. Its residents were expelled, and the village was destroyed. Its lands were later incorporated into the Israeli settlement of Givat Oz.

name: Umm al-'Amad
story: A village in the Jezreel Valley, Umm al-'Amad was depopulated on April 12, 1948. It was one of the villages cleared by the Haganah during the Battle of Mishmar HaEmek. The villagers were forced to flee, and their homes were demolished. The Israeli settlement of Allonei Abba was established on its lands in 1948.

name: 'Allar
story: A village perched on a rocky hill in the Jerusalem corridor, 'Allar's economy was based on agriculture, primarily grains, vegetables, and olives from which oil was pressed in a local mill. The village was depopulated on October 22, 1948, during Operation ha-Har, an offensive by the Harel Brigade aimed at clearing the region south of the Jerusalem-Jaffa road. The operation involved systematically taking village after village, causing inhabitants to flee from the advancing forces and shelling. After its capture, 'Allar was completely destroyed.
