The Israeli settlement of Mata and parts of the 'American Independence Park,' funded by the Jewish National Fund, were established on its lands.

name: Beit Thul
story: A village located on a mountaintop, Beit Thul was depopulated in April 1948 during Operation Nachshon. The village was one of many in the Jerusalem corridor cleared by the Haganah to secure the road to the city. Its inhabitants were forced to flee, and the village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Neve Ilan was established on its lands in 1946 and re-established in 1971 after being abandoned.

name: Jaba'
story: Not to be confused with the Jaba' in the Haifa district, this village was located northeast of Jerusalem. It was not depopulated during the 1948 war but fell on the Jordanian side of the armistice line. It was subsequently occupied by Israel in the 1967 war and remains a Palestinian village under occupation today, facing land confiscation for the expansion of nearby illegal settlements.

name: Khirbat al-Deir
story: A small village in the Hebron hills, Khirbat al-Deir was depopulated in 1948. Its capture was part of the general advance of Israeli forces into the Hebron area during Operation Yoav in late October. The residents were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The area is now designated as agricultural land for Israeli settlements.

name: al-Qubayba
story: Not to be confused with the village of the same name near Jerusalem, this al-Qubayba was located in the western Hebron district. It was captured by the Givati Brigade on October 28, 1948, during Operation Yoav. This was part of the final push to clear the southern front. After the villagers were expelled, the village was destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Lakhish was established on its lands in 1955.

name: al-Majd
story: A village in the southern Hebron hills, al-Majd was depopulated during the 1948 war. Its residents were forced to flee by the advance of Israeli forces into the area. The village was destroyed, and its lands were expropriated by the state. The Israeli settlement of Lahav was established nearby.

name: al-'Abisiyya
story: A large village east of Jaffa, formerly known as al-Yahudiyya. The Irgun first attacked in December 1947. The village was finally occupied by the Irgun on May 4, 1948, during Operation Hametz. The inhabitants were expelled. In September 1948, David Ben-Gurion received cabinet permission to destroy the village to prevent the return of its inhabitants. The Israeli town of Yehud now stands on its ruins.
israeli_settlement: Yehud, Magshimim, Ganne Yehuda, Ganne Tiqwa, Savyon

name: al-Sawalima
story: Al-Sawalima was a village inhabited by Bedouins, located on the coast north of the al-'Awja river. It was depopulated on March 30, 1948, during the systematic Haganah campaign to clear the coastal plain. The villagers were forced out of their homes under military pressure. The village was subsequently destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the Israeli city of Herzliya.

name: Danna
story: A village in the hills on the edge of the Baysan valley, Danna was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 15, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Lahavot Haviva was later established on its lands.

name: Tall al-Shawk
story: A small village just south of Baysan city, Tall al-Shawk was depopulated on May 12, 1948. It was captured by the Golani Brigade during the initial phase of Operation Gideon. The operation focused on clearing the villages surrounding the city of Baysan to facilitate its capture. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Sde Trumot was established nearby and its lands now cover the site of the former village.

name: al-Bira
story: A village situated in the Baysan Valley, al-Bira was known for its numerous springs and fertile lands. It was captured by the Golani Brigade on May 16, 1948, during Operation Gideon. The operation aimed to create a continuous strip of Israeli-controlled territory and preempt the entry of Arab armies. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was subsequently demolished. The Israeli settlement of Ein ha-Natziv was established on its lands in 1946 and later expanded over the village site after its destruction.

name: 'Absiyya
story: A small village in the northern Hula Valley, 'Absiyya was depopulated in May 1948 during Operation Yiftach. The operation's goal was to ethnically cleanse the entire eastern Galilee of its Palestinian population. The villagers were forced to flee, many seeking refuge in Syria. The village was later destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Lehavot HaBashan was established on its lands.

name: al-Thahiriyya al-Fawqa
story: The 'upper' of two villages named al-Thahiriyya, it was located just north of Safad. It was depopulated in May 1948 following the fall of Safad during Operation Yiftach. The terror induced by the city's capture caused the villagers to flee for their lives. The village was then destroyed, and its lands were absorbed by the expanding Israeli settlement of Rosh Pinna.

name: Khirbat al-Zababida
story: A small agricultural community in the Tulkarm sub-district, Khirbat al-Zababida was depopulated in 1948. It was one of many small localities cleared by Haganah forces as they consolidated control over the coastal plain. The residents were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. Its lands were later taken over by the Israeli settlement of Ma'anit.

name: Miski
story: A village on the coastal plain, Miski was depopulated on April 21, 1948. It was captured by the Alexandroni Brigade as part of the operations to clear the area around the main coastal highway. The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mishmeret was established on its lands.

name: al-Jibil
story: A Bedouin locality in the Negev, al-Jibil was depopulated in 1949 as part of the post-war Israeli military operations to remove the Bedouin population from large swathes of the desert. The residents were forcibly relocated to a restricted zone, and their traditional lands were expropriated by the state for military use and settlement.

name: al-Muzayri'a
story: A large village near Lydda, al-Muzayri'a was captured on July 12, 1948, by the Kiryati and Alexandroni brigades during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the encirclement of Lydda and Ramla. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mazor was established on its lands in 1949.

name: al-Qastal
story: A small but strategically vital village built around a Roman and Crusader fort (Castellum) that commanded the main Jaffa-Jerusalem highway. Al-Qastal became the site of one of the most famous battles of the 1948 war. It was a critical target of Operation Nachshon, the Haganah's first major offensive to break the siege of Jerusalem. It was initially occupied by the Palmach on April 3, 1948. A fierce multi-day battle ensued, during which the charismatic Palestinian commander 'Abd al-Qadir al-Husayni was killed while leading a counter-attack. After its final capture on April 8-9, Palmach units systematically blew up the village's houses, setting a precedent for the destruction of other villages in the corridor. The Israeli settlement of Ma'oz Tziyyon, later merged into Mevasseret Zion, was built on its site.

name: Qalunya
story: A village on the main Jaffa-Jerusalem highway, identified with the Roman settlement of Colonia Amosa and the biblical town of Motza. It was a primary target of Operation Nachshon. On April 11, 1948, after the battle for al-Qastal, Palmach units entered Qalunya and systematically blew up 50 houses, leaving the village ablaze. The remaining inhabitants were ordered out before the destruction. This act of deliberate destruction was one of the first of its kind in the Jerusalem corridor and served as a clear message to other Palestinian communities. The Israeli settlement of Mevasseret Zion was later established on its lands.

name: al-Walaja
story: An agricultural village southwest of Jerusalem, al-Walaja was captured on October 21, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Ha-Har. After its residents were expelled, the village was completely destroyed. The armistice line of 1949 was drawn through its lands, with the village site itself falling on the Israeli side. The villagers rebuilt their community on the Jordanian side of the line, but this 'new' al-Walaja was then occupied by Israel in 1967. The community has since been subjected to continuous land confiscation for the construction of the Apartheid Wall and the illegal settlements of Har Gilo and Gilo, strangling the village in a concrete grip.

name: Saris
story: A village perched on a high plateau west of Jerusalem, Saris was attacked and demolished by the Haganah on April 16, 1948, during Operation Nachshon. The Scotsman newspaper reported the destruction of its mosque, a school, and 25 houses. Just before the attack, Haganah chief Israel Galili requested that a settlement be established at Saris 'as soon as possible' for security reasons, revealing the pre-meditated plan of replacement that followed expulsion and destruction. The Israeli settlement of Shoresh was later built on its ruins.

name: Sataf
story: An ancient village built on a steep hillside, Sataf was renowned for its sophisticated agricultural terraces and springs. It was captured on July 13-14, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Dani. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The site was later turned into an Israeli tourist park and recreation area managed by the Jewish National Fund (JNF), which presents the ancient terraces as a generic 'biblical' landscape while completely erasing the memory and heritage of the Palestinian farmers who built and maintained them for centuries.

name: Suba
story: Located on a strategic mountaintop west of Jerusalem, Suba was built within the ruins of the formidable Crusader fortress of Belmont. Its houses were clustered inside the castle's ancient walls. The village was captured on the night of July 12-13, 1948, by the Harel Brigade during Operation Dani. According to an Associated Press report at the time, the village was taken 'without combat after a bombardment that drove the Arab defenders' from the strategic heights. The residents who had not already fled the shelling were expelled. The site was later used to establish Kibbutz Tzova, and a forest was planted over much of the village lands, obscuring its history.

name: Barfiliya
story: A village located on a rocky hill near the town of Lydda, Barfiliya was captured on July 14, 1948, by the 8th Armored Brigade and the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the second phase of the operation after the fall of Lydda and Ramla. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The village lands are now covered by forests planted by the JNF, and the Israeli settlement of Kfar Rut was established nearby.

name: Bashshit
story: Bashshit was a large village on the southern coastal plain, known for its shrine to a local sage, Nabi Shit (the Prophet Seth). It was depopulated on May 11, 1948, by the Givati Brigade during Operation Barak. The operation's goal was to ethnically cleanse the area around several key roads. The villagers were forced to flee their homes under military assault. The village was later destroyed, though the shrine remains. The Israeli settlements of Aseret, Giv'at Washington, and Kfar Mordechai were established on its lands.

name: Bayt Nabala
story: A large village located on a hilltop, Bayt Nabala was historically significant and had a station on the Jaffa-Lydda railway. It was captured on May 13, 1948, by the Alexandroni Brigade. The attack was preceded by a mortar barrage. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. A report by an Israeli intelligence officer noted that the destruction of Bayt Nabala and surrounding villages had a 'positive effect' by encouraging the flight of residents from Lydda and Ramla. The settlement of Beit Nehemia was established on its lands.

name: Bayt Shanna
story: A small village in the Latrun salient, Bayt Shanna was depopulated on July 15-16, 1948, during Operation Dani. After the fall of Lydda and Ramla, Israeli forces pushed into the surrounding hills. The village was captured by the Yiftach Brigade. Its inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed as part of the effort to create a depopulated 'no-man's land' in the Latrun area. The site is now covered by a forest planted by the JNF.

name: Bayt Susin
story: Located on a hilltop overlooking the coastal plain, Bayt Susin was depopulated in May 1948. It was captured during Operation Makkabi, which aimed to clear the Jerusalem corridor. The village was attacked, and its residents were forced to flee. The village was subsequently destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Ta'oz was established on its lands in 1950. The site is now part of a forest.

name: Bir Ma'in
story: A village located on a rocky plateau, Bir Ma'in was captured on July 15, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Its capture was part of the second stage of the operation, expanding control east of Lydda. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Mevo Modi'im was later established on its lands.

name: Burj
story: A small village in the Latrun salient, Burj was captured on July 15, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. Like other villages in the area (Bayt Shanna, Bir Ma'in), its capture and destruction were part of the plan to ethnically cleanse the Latrun area and widen the corridor to Jerusalem. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were demolished. The site of the former village is now covered by forest.

name: Daniyal
story: A village named after a shrine it contained, believed to be the tomb of the Prophet Daniel, Daniyal was captured on July 10, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade during Operation Dani. The capture was part of the initial assault on the 'Lydda pocket.' The villagers were expelled from their homes, and the village was destroyed, with the exception of the shrine. The Israeli settlement of Kfar Daniel was established on its lands in 1949, directly appropriating its name.

name: Dayr Tarif
story: A large village near Lydda, Dayr Tarif was captured on July 10, 1948, by the Kiryati Brigade and the 8th Armored Brigade during Operation Dani. The village put up a defense but was eventually overwhelmed. The inhabitants were expelled, and the village was completely destroyed. The Israeli settlement of Beit Arif was established on its lands.

name: Haditha
story: A village with ancient origins, mentioned by the Roman historian Josephus. It was located near the city of Lydda. The village was captured on July 12, 1948, by the Yiftach Brigade as part of Operation Dani. Its capture occurred in conjunction with the infamous assault on Lydda and Ramla, which involved a large-scale massacre and the forced expulsion of some 70,000 civilians. The inhabitants of Haditha were also expelled. The Israeli settlement of Hadid was established on its ruins in 1949.

name: Khirbat Bayt Far
story: A small village in the Ramle sub-district, Khirbat Bayt Far was depopulated on May 15, 1948, during Operation Makkabi. The offensive cleared the area along the Jerusalem road. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed. The site of the former village is now part of an industrial zone.

name: al-Nabi Yusha'
story: A small Shi'a Muslim village built around a revered shrine for the Prophet Joshua. It was located on a strategic hilltop overlooking the Hula Valley. The British handed over the police fort next to the village to Haganah forces in April 1948. After repelling two major Palmach attacks that resulted in heavy Israeli casualties, the village was finally captured on May 17 during Operation Yiftach. The villagers were expelled, and their homes were destroyed, but the shrine remains. The Israeli settlement of Ramot Naftali was established on its lands.

name: Lydda
story: Lydda was a major, ancient Palestinian city and a critical transportation hub. On July 11-12, 1948, during Operation Dani, it was captured by the Yiftach Brigade under the command of Yigal Allon and Yitzhak Rabin. The capture was accompanied by a brutal massacre. After a brief skirmish, Israeli soldiers opened fire indiscriminately in the city streets and stormed the Dahmash Mosque, where hundreds of civilians were taking shelter, killing between 100 and 250 people. Following the massacre, the city's 50,000-70,000 residents (including refugees) were forcibly expelled on foot in a notorious 'death march' towards the Jordanian lines. The city was then resettled by Jewish immigrants and renamed Lod.

name: al-Ramla
story: The historic capital of the Jund Filastin district, al-Ramla was a major Palestinian city with a vibrant social and economic life. It was captured on July 12, 1948, immediately after the fall of Lydda, during Operation Dani. While a massacre on the scale of Lydda's did not occur here, the terror from the adjacent city, combined with shelling and the Israeli occupation, prompted the city's leadership to surrender. Along with the population of Lydda, the vast majority of Ramla's Palestinian inhabitants were systematically and forcibly expelled in the 'death march' towards the Jordanian lines. The city was then resettled by Jewish immigrants and became the Israeli city of Ramla.

name: Jaffa
story: Jaffa was the cultural, financial, and political heart of Palestine, a bustling port city renowned for its citrus exports, newspapers, and theaters. It was subjected to a campaign of terror and attack for months. The Irgun (IZL) militia launched a major offensive against the city on April 25, 1948, subjecting it to a relentless mortar bombardment. Haganah forces joined the assault in Operation Hametz, completing the encirclement. The city fell on May 13. Of its original population of over 70,000, only about 4,000 remained. The rest were expelled or fled in terror, many by sea. Jaffa was then annexed to Tel Aviv, its identity and history systematically suppressed.

name: Haifa
story: A major port city with a mixed population, Haifa was a center of industry and intellectual life. On April 21-22, 1948, Haganah forces launched a major offensive to capture the city. The assault included psychological warfare, with loudspeaker vans broadcasting threats of 'what happened at Deir Yassin,' and rolling explosive-filled barrels down the steep slopes of Mount Carmel into Palestinian neighborhoods. This created mass panic. The British army, which was still present, facilitated the evacuation of the Palestinian population by sea. Of Haifa's more than 70,000 Palestinian residents, only 3,000-4,000 remained. The city was ethnically cleansed in a matter of days.

name: Acre
story: An ancient walled city with a rich history, Acre was captured by Haganah forces on May 17, 1948, during Operation Ben-Ami. The attack began with a heavy mortar bombardment and an outbreak of typhoid, which some sources attribute to deliberate biological warfare by the Haganah. The city's defenders were overwhelmed, and after its fall, a large part of its Palestinian population was expelled or fled. The Old City was largely preserved, but its inhabitants were displaced, and the city's character was fundamentally altered.

name: Safad
story: A city with a large Palestinian majority and a small Jewish quarter, Safad was a key objective of Operation Yiftach. The campaign to capture it began with massacres and psychological warfare in surrounding villages like 'Ayn al-Zaytun. On May 10, 1948, Haganah forces launched a major assault, bombarding the city's Arab quarters heavily. The combination of the military assault and the terror induced by the surrounding massacres led to a mass flight of the city's 12,000 Palestinian residents. The city was captured on May 11 and completely cleansed of its indigenous population.

name: Beisan
story: An ancient city on the site of the Roman Scythopolis, Beisan was the urban center of the fertile Beisan Valley. It was captured on May 12, 1948, by the Golani Brigade during Operation Gideon. The operation systematically cleared the entire valley. After a brief battle, the city surrendered. Its Palestinian inhabitants were initially allowed to stay but were then systematically expelled over the following weeks, most driven across the Jordan River. The city was then resettled by Jewish immigrants and renamed Beit She'an.
